 Conflict of the Saracens, <NORP>Latins</NORP> and Greeks, in Italy, A.
D.
 840-1017 The <CARDINAL>three</CARDINAL> great nations of the world, the Greeks, the Saracens, and the Franks, encountered each other on the theatre of Italy.
 (1) The southern provinces, which now compose the kingdom of Naples, were subject, for the most part, to the <GPE>Lombard</GPE> dukes and princes of Beneventum; (2) so powerful in war, that they checked for a moment the genius of Charlemagne; so liberal in peace, that they maintained in their capital an academy of <CARDINAL>thirty-two</CARDINAL> philosophers and grammarians.
 The division of this flourishing state produced the rival principalities of Benevento, Salerno, and Capua; and the thoughtless ambition or revenge of the competitors invited the <NORP>Saracens</NORP> to the ruin of their common inheritance.
 During a calamitous period of <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> hundred years, <GPE>Italy</GPE> was exposed to a repetition of wounds, which the invaders were not capable of healing by the union and tranquility of a perfect conquest.
 Their frequent and almost annual squadrons issued from the port of Palermo, and were entertained with too much indulgence by the <NORP>Christians</NORP> of Naples: the more formidable fleets were prepared on the <NORP>African</NORP> coast; and even the <NORP>Arabs</NORP> of <GPE>Andalusia</GPE> were sometimes tempted to assist or oppose the <NORP>Moslems</NORP> of an adverse sect.
 In the revolution of human events, a new ambuscade was concealed in the Caudine Forks, the fields of <GPE>Cannae</GPE> were bedewed a <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> time with the blood of the Africans, and the sovereign of <GPE>Rome</GPE> again attacked or defended the walls of <GPE>Capua</GPE> and Tarentum.
 A colony of <NORP>Saracens</NORP> had been planted at Bari, which commands the entrance of the <LOC>Adriatic</LOC> Gulf; and their impartial depredations provoked the resentment, and conciliated the union of the <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> emperors.
 An offensive alliance was concluded between <PERSON>Basil</PERSON> the Macedonian, the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> of his race, and <PERSON>Lewis</PERSON> the great-grandson of Charlemagne; (3) and each party supplied the deficiencies of his associate.
 It would have been imprudent in the <NORP>Byzantine</NORP> monarch to transport his stationary troops of <LOC>Asia</LOC> to an <NORP>Italian</NORP> campaign; and the <NORP>Latin</NORP> arms would have been insufficient if his superior navy had not occupied the mouth of the Gulf.
 Conquest of Bari, A.
D.
 871.
 The fortress of <PERSON>Bari</PERSON> was invested by the infantry of the Franks, and by the cavalry and galleys of the Greeks; and, after a defence of <CARDINAL>four</CARDINAL> years, the <NORP>Arabian</NORP> emir submitted to the clemency of Lewis, who commanded in person the operations of the siege.
 This important conquest had been achieved by the concord of the <LOC>East</LOC> and West; but their recent amity was soon embittered by the mutual complaints of jealousy and pride.
 The <NORP>Greeks</NORP> assumed as their own the merit of the conquest and the pomp of the triumph; extolled the greatness of their powers, and affected to deride the intemperance and sloth of the handful of <NORP>Barbarians</NORP> who appeared under the banners of the <NORP>Carlovingian</NORP> prince.

 These lofty hopes were soon extinguished by the death of Lewis, and the decay of the <NORP>Carlovingian</NORP> house; and whoever might deserve the honour, the <NORP>Greek</NORP> emperors, Basil, and his son Leo, secured the advantage, of the reduction of <PERSON>Bari</PERSON> The <NORP>Italians</NORP> of <GPE>Apulia</GPE> and <GPE>Calabria</GPE> were persuaded or compelled to acknowledge their supremacy, and an ideal line from Mount Garganus to the Bay of Salerno, leaves the far greater part of the kingdom of <GPE>Naples</GPE> under the dominion of the <NORP>Eastern</NORP> empire.
 Beyond that line, the dukes or republics of <GPE>Amalfi</GPE> (5) and Naples, who had never forfeited their voluntary allegiance, rejoiced in the neighbourhood of their lawful sovereign; and <GPE>Amalfi</GPE> was enriched by supplying <LOC>Europe</LOC> with the produce and manufactures of Asia.
 But the <GPE>Lombard</GPE> princes of Benevento, Salerno, and Capua, (6) were reluctantly torn from the communion of the <NORP>Latin</NORP> world, and too often violated their oaths of servitude and tribute.
 The city of <PERSON>Bari</PERSON> rose to dignity and wealth, as the metropolis of the new theme or province of Lombardy: the title of patrician, and afterwards the singular name of Catapan, (7) was assigned to the supreme governor; and the policy both of the church and state was modelled in exact subordination to the throne of Constantinople.
 As long as the sceptre was disputed by the princes of Italy, their efforts were feeble and adverse; and the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> resisted or eluded the forces of Germany, which descended from the <LOC>Alps</LOC> under the <NORP>Imperial</NORP> standard of the Othos.
 The <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> and greatest of those <NORP>Saxon</NORP> princes was compelled to relinquish the siege of Bari: the second, after the loss of his stoutest bishops and barons, escaped with honour from the bloody field of Crotona.
 Defeat of Otho III, A.
D.
983.
 On that day the scale of war was turned against the <PERSON>Franks</PERSON> by the valour of the Saracens.
 (8) These corsairs had indeed been driven by the <NORP>Byzantine</NORP> fleets from the fortresses and coasts of Italy; but a sense of interest was more prevalent than superstition or resentment, and the caliph of <GPE>Egypt</GPE> had transported <CARDINAL>forty</CARDINAL> thousand <NORP>Moslems</NORP> to the aid of his <NORP>Christian</NORP> ally.
 The successors of <PERSON>Basil</PERSON> amused themselves with the belief, that the conquest of <GPE>Lombardy</GPE> had been achieved, and was still preserved by the justice of their laws, the virtues of their ministers, and the gratitude of a people whom they had rescued from anarchy and oppression.
 A series of rebellions might dart a ray of truth into the palace of Constantinople; and the illusions of flattery were dispelled by the easy and rapid success of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> adventurers.
 Anecdotes.
 The revolution of human affairs had produced in <GPE>Apulia</GPE> and <GPE>Calabria</GPE> a melancholy contrast between the age of <PERSON>Pythagoras</PERSON> and the tenth century of the <NORP>Christian</NORP> aera.
 At the former period, the coast of Great <GPE>Greece</GPE> (as it was then styled) was planted with free and opulent cities: these cities were peopled with soldiers, artists, and philosophers; and the military strength of Tarentum; Sybaris, or Crotona, was not inferior to that of a powerful kingdom.
 At the <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> aera, these once flourishing provinces were clouded with ignorance impoverished by tyranny, and depopulated by <NORP>Barbarian</NORP> war nor can we severely accuse the exaggeration of a contemporary, that a fair and ample district was reduced to the same desolation which had covered the earth after the general deluge.
 (9) Among the hostilities of the Arabs, the Franks, and the Greeks, in the southern Italy, I shall select <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> or <CARDINAL>three</CARDINAL> anecdotes expressive of their national manners.
 A.
D.
 873.
 1.
 It was the amusement of the <NORP>Saracens</NORP> to profane, as well as to pillage, the monasteries and churches.
 At the siege of Salerno, a <NORP>Mussulman</NORP> chief spread his couch on the communion-table, and on that altar sacrificed each night the virginity of a <NORP>Christian</NORP> nun.
 As he wrestled with a reluctant maid, a beam in the roof was accidentally or dexterously thrown down on his head; and the death of the lustful emir was imputed to the wrath of Christ, which was at length awakened to the defence of his faithful spouse.
 (10) A.
D.
 874.
 2.
 The <NORP>Saracens</NORP> besieged the cities of <GPE>Beneventum</GPE> and Capua: after a vain appeal to the successors of Charlemagne, the <NORP>Lombards</NORP> implored the clemency and aid of the <NORP>Greek</NORP> emperor.
 (11) A fearless citizen dropped from the walls, passed the entrenchments, accomplished his commission, and fell into the hands of the <NORP>Barbarians</NORP> as he was returning with the welcome news.
 They commanded him to assist their enterprise, and deceive his countrymen, with the assurance that wealth and honours should be the reward of his falsehood, and that his sincerity would be punished with immediate death.
 He affected to yield, but as soon as he was conducted within hearing of the <NORP>Christians</NORP> on the rampart, "Friends and brethren," he cried with a loud voice, "be bold and patient, maintain the city; your sovereign is informed of your distress, and your deliverers are at hand.
 I know my doom, and commit my wife and children to your gratitude.
" The rage of the <NORP>Arabs</NORP> confirmed his evidence; and the self-devoted patriot was transpierced with a hundred spears.
 He deserves to live in the memory of the virtuous, but the repetition of the same story in ancient and modern times, may sprinkle some doubts on the reality of this generous deed.
 (12) A.
D.
 930.
 3.
 The recital of a <ORDINAL>third</ORDINAL> incident may provoke a smile amidst the horrors of war.
 Theobald, marquis of <GPE>Camerino</GPE> and Spoleto, (13) supported the rebels of Beneventum; and his wanton cruelty was not incompatible in that age with the character of a hero.
 His captives of the <NORP>Greek</NORP> nation or party were castrated without mercy, and the outrage was aggravated by a cruel jest, that he wished to present the emperor with a supply of eunuchs, the most precious ornaments of the <NORP>Byzantine</NORP> court.
 The garrison of a castle had been defeated in a sally, and the prisoners were sentenced to the customary operation.
 But the sacrifice was disturbed by the intrusion of a frantic female, who, with bleeding cheeks dishevelled hair, and importunate clamours, compelled the marquis to listen to her complaint.
 "Is it thus," she cried, "ye magnanimous heroes, that ye wage war against women, against women who have never injured ye, and whose only arms are the distaff and the loom?" <PERSON>Theobald</PERSON> denied the charge, and protested that, since the Amazons, he had never heard of a female war.
 "And how," she furiously exclaimed, "can you attack us more directly, how can you wound us in a more vital part, than by robbing our husbands of what we most dearly cherish, the source of our joys, and the hope of our posterity? The plunder of our flocks and herds I have endured without a murmur, but this fatal injury, this irreparable loss, subdues my patience, and calls aloud on the justice of heaven and earth.
" A general laugh applauded her eloquence; the savage Franks, inaccessible to pity, were moved by her ridiculous, yet rational despair; and with the deliverance of the captives, she obtained the restitution of her effects.
 As she returned in triumph to the castle, she was overtaken by a messenger, to inquire, in the name of Theobald, what punishment should be inflicted on her husband, were he again taken in arms.
 "Should such," she answered without hesitation, "be his guilt and misfortune, he has eyes, and a nose, and hands, and feet.
 These are his own, and these he may deserve to forfeit by his personal offences.
 But let my (14) lord be pleased to spare what his little handmaid presumes to claim as her peculiar and lawful property.
" Origin of the <NORP>Normans</NORP> in Italy, A.
D.
 1016.
 The establishment of the <NORP>Normans</NORP> in the kingdoms of <GPE>Naples</GPE> and <GPE>Sicily</GPE> (15) is an event most romantic in its origin, and in its consequences most important both to <GPE>Italy</GPE> and the <NORP>Eastern</NORP> empire.
 The broken provinces of the Greeks, Lombards, and Saracens, were exposed to every invader, and every sea and land were invaded by the adventurous spirit of the <NORP>Scandinavian</NORP> pirates.
 After a long indulgence of rapine and slaughter, a fair and ample territory was accepted, occupied, and named, by the <NORP>Normans</NORP> of France: they renounced their gods for the God of the Christians; (16) and the dukes of <GPE>Normandy</GPE> acknowledged themselves the vassals of the successors of <PERSON>Charlemagne</PERSON> and Capet.
 The savage fierceness which they had brought from the snowy mountains of <GPE>Norway</GPE> was refined, without being corrupted, in a warmer climate; the companions of <PERSON>Rollo</PERSON> insensibly mingled with the natives; they imbibed the manners, language, (17) and gallantry, of the <NORP>French</NORP> nation; and in a martial age, the <NORP>Normans</NORP> might claim the palm of valour and glorious achievements.
 Of the fashionable superstitions, they embraced with ardour the pilgrimages of Rome, Italy, and the Holy Land.
 In this active devotion, the minds and bodies were invigorated by exercise: danger was the incentive, novelty the recompense; and the prospect of the world was decorated by wonder, credulity, and ambitious hope.
 They confederated for their mutual defence; and the robbers of the Alps, who had been allured by the garb of a pilgrim, were often chastised by the arm of a warrior.
 In <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> of these pious visits to the cavern of Mount Garganus in Apulia, which had been sanctified by the apparition of the archangel Michael, (18) they were accosted by a stranger in the <NORP>Greek</NORP> habit, but who soon revealed himself as a rebel, a fugitive, and a mortal foe of the <NORP>Greek</NORP> empire.
 His name was Melo; a noble citizen of Bari, who, after an unsuccessful revolt, was compelled to seek new allies and avengers of his country.
 The bold appearance of the <NORP>Normans</NORP> revived his hopes and solicited his confidence: they listened to the complaints, and still more to the promises, of the patriot.
 The assurance of wealth demonstrated the justice of his cause; and they viewed, as the inheritance of the brave, the fruitful land which was oppressed by effeminate tyrants.
 On their return to Normandy, they kindled a spark of enterprise, and a small but intrepid band was freely associated for the deliverance of Apulia.
 They passed the <LOC>Alps</LOC> by separate roads, and in the disguise of pilgrims; but in the neighbourhood of <GPE>Rome</GPE> they were saluted by the chief of Bari, who supplied the more indigent with arms and horses, and instantly led them to the field of action.
 In the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> conflict, their valour prevailed; but in the <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> engagement they were overwhelmed by the numbers and military engines of the Greeks, and indignantly retreated with their faces to .
 the enemy.
 The unfortunate <PERSON>Melo</PERSON> ended his life a suppliant at the court of Germany: his <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> followers, excluded from their native and their promised land, wandered among the hills and valleys of Italy, and earned their daily subsistence by the sword.
 To that formidable sword the princes of Capua, Beneventum, Salerno, and Naples, alternately appealed in their domestic quarrels; the superior spirit and discipline of the <NORP>Normans</NORP> gave victory to the side which they espoused; and their cautious policy observed the balance of power, lest the preponderance of any rival state should render their aid less important, and their service less profitable.
 Their <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> asylum was a strong camp in the depth of the marshes of Campania: but they were soon endowed by the liberality of the duke of <GPE>Naples</GPE> with a more plentiful and permanent seat.
 Foundation of Aversa, A.
D.
 1029.
 Eight miles from his residence, as a bulwark against Capua, the town of <PERSON>Aversa</PERSON> was built and fortified for their use; and they enjoyed as their own the corn and fruits, the meadows and groves, of that fertile district.
 The report of their success attracted every year new swarms of pilgrims and soldiers: the poor were urged by necessity; the rich were excited by hope; and the brave and active spirits of <GPE>Normandy</GPE> were impatient of ease and ambitious of renown.
 The independent standard of <PERSON>Aversa</PERSON> afforded shelter and encouragement to the outlaws of the province, to every fugitive who had escaped from the injustice or justice of his superiors; and these foreign associates were quickly assimilated in manners and language to the <NORP>Gallic</NORP> colony.
 The <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> leader of the <NORP>Normans</NORP> was Count Rainulf; and, in the origin of society, pre-eminence of rank is the reward and the proof of superior merit.
 (19) The <NORP>Normans</NORP> serve in Sicily, A.
D.
 1038.
 Since the conquest of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> by the Arabs, the <NORP>Grecian</NORP> emperors had been anxious to regain that valuable possession; but their efforts, however strenuous, had been opposed by the distance and the sea.
 Their costly armaments, after a gleam of success, added new pages of calamity and disgrace to the <NORP>Byzantine</NORP> annals: <CARDINAL>twenty</CARDINAL> thousand of their best troops were lost in a single expedition; and the victorious <NORP>Moslems</NORP> derided the policy of a nation which entrusted eunuchs not only with the custody of their women, but with the command of their men (20) After a reign of <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> hundred years, the <NORP>Saracens</NORP> were ruined by their divisions.
 (21) The emir disclaimed the authority of the king of Tunis; the people rose against the emir; the cities were usurped by the chiefs; each meaner rebel was independent in his village or castle; and the weaker of <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> rival brothers implored the friendship of the Christians.
 In every service of danger the <NORP>Normans</NORP> were prompt and useful; and <CARDINAL>five</CARDINAL> hundred knights, or warriors on horseback, were enrolled by Arduin, the agent and interpreter of the Greeks, under the standard of Maniaces, governor of Lombardy.
 Before their landing, the brothers were reconciled; the union of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> and <LOC>Africa</LOC> was restored; and the island was guarded to the water's edge.
 The <NORP>Normans</NORP> led the van and the <NORP>Arabs</NORP> of <GPE>Messina</GPE> felt the valour of an untried foe.
 In a <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> action the emir of <GPE>Syracuse</GPE> was unhorsed and transpierced by the iron arm of <PERSON>William</PERSON> of Hauteville.
 In a <ORDINAL>third</ORDINAL> engagement, his intrepid companions discomfited the host of sixty thousand Saracens, and left the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> no more than the labor of the pursuit: a splendid victory; but of which the pen of the historian may divide the merit with the lance of the Normans.
 It is, however, true, that they essentially promoted the success of Maniaces, who reduced <CARDINAL>thirteen</CARDINAL> cities, and the greater part of Sicily, under the obedience of the emperor.
 But his military fame was sullied by ingratitude and tyranny.
 In the division of the spoils, the deserts of his brave auxiliaries were forgotten; and neither their avarice nor their pride could brook this injurious treatment.
 They complained by the mouth of their interpreter: their complaint was disregarded; their interpreter was scourged; the sufferings were his; the insult and resentment belonged to those whose sentiments he had delivered.
 Yet they dissembled till they had obtained, or stolen, a safe passage to the <NORP>Italian</NORP> continent: their brethren of <PERSON>Aversa</PERSON> sympathized in their indignation, and the province of <GPE>Apulia</GPE> was invaded as the forfeit of the debt.
 (22) Their conquest of Apulia, A.
D.
 1040-1043.
 Above <CARDINAL>twenty</CARDINAL> <DATE>years</DATE> after the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> emigration, the <NORP>Normans</NORP> took the field with no more than <CARDINAL>seven</CARDINAL> hundred horse and <CARDINAL>five</CARDINAL> hundred foot; and after the recall of the <NORP>Byzantine</NORP> legions (23) from the <NORP>Sicilian</NORP> war, their numbers are magnified to the amount of threescore thousand men.
 Their herald proposed the option of battle or retreat; "of battle," was the unanimous cry of the Normans; and <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> of their stoutest warriors, with a stroke of his fist, felled to the ground the horse of the <NORP>Greek</NORP> messenger.
 He was dismissed with a fresh horse; the insult was concealed from the <NORP>Imperial</NORP> troops; but in <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> successive battles they were more fatally instructed of the prowess of their adversaries.
 In the plains of Cannae, the <NORP>Asiatics</NORP> fled before the adventurers of France; the duke of <GPE>Lombardy</GPE> was made prisoner; the <NORP>Apulians</NORP> acquiesced in a new dominion; and the <CARDINAL>four</CARDINAL> places of Bari, Otranto, Brundusium, and Tarentum, were alone saved in the shipwreck of the <NORP>Grecian</NORP> fortunes.
 From this aera we may date the establishment of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> power, which soon eclipsed the infant colony of Aversa.
 <CARDINAL>Twelve</CARDINAL> counts (24) were chosen by the popular suffrage; and age, birth, and merit, were the motives of their choice.
 The tributes of their peculiar districts were appropriated to their use; and each count erected a fortress in the midst of his lands, and at the head of his vassals.
 In the centre of the province, the common habitation of <ORG>Melphi</ORG> was reserved as the metropolis and citadel of the republic; a house and separate <CARDINAL>quarter</CARDINAL> was allotted to each of the <CARDINAL>twelve</CARDINAL> counts: and the national concerns were regulated by this military senate.
 The <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> of his peers, their president and general, was entitled count of Apulia; and this dignity was conferred on <PERSON>William</PERSON> of the iron arm, who, in the language of the age, is styled a lion in battle, a lamb in society, and an angel in council.
 (25) Character of the Normans.
 The manners of his countrymen are fairly delineated by a contemporary and national historian.
 (26) "The Normans," says Malaterra, "are a cunning and revengeful people; eloquence and dissimulation appear to be their hereditary qualities: they can stoop to flatter; but unless they are curbed by the restraint of law, they indulge the licentiousness of nature and passion.
 Their princes affect the praises of popular munificence; the people observe the medium, or rather blend the extremes, of avarice and prodigality; and in their eager thirst of wealth and dominion, they despise whatever they possess, and hope whatever they desire.
 Arms and horses, the luxury of dress, the exercises of hunting and hawking (27) are the delight of the Normans; but, on pressing occasions, they can endure with incredible patience the inclemency of every climate, and the toil and absence of a military life.
" (28) Oppression of Apulia,A.
D.
 1046 etc.
 The <NORP>Normans</NORP> of <GPE>Apulia</GPE> were seated on the verge of the <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> empires; and, according to the policy of the hour, they accepted the investiture of their lands, from the sovereigns of <GPE>Germany</GPE> or Constantinople.
 But the firmest title of these adventurers was the right of conquest: they neither loved nor trusted; they were neither trusted nor beloved: the contempt of the princes was mixed with fear, and the fear of the natives was mingled with hatred and resentment.
 Every object of desire, a horse, a woman, a garden, tempted and gratified the rapaciousness of the strangers; (29) and the avarice of their chiefs was only colored by the more specious names of ambition and glory.
 The <CARDINAL>twelve</CARDINAL> counts were sometimes joined in the league of injustice: in their domestic quarrels they disputed the spoils of the people: the virtues of <PERSON>William</PERSON> were buried in his grave; and Drogo, his brother and successor, was better qualified to lead the valour, than to restrain the violence, of his peers.
 Under the reign of <PERSON>Constantine</PERSON> Monomachus, the policy, rather than benevolence, of the <NORP>Byzantine</NORP> court, attempted to relieve <GPE>Italy</GPE> from this adherent mischief, more grievous than a flight of Barbarians; (30) and Argyrus, the son of Melo, was invested for this purpose with the most lofty titles (31) and the most ample commission.
 The memory of his father might recommend him to the Normans; and he had already engaged their voluntary service to quell the revolt of Maniaces, and to avenge their own and the public injury.
 It was the design of <PERSON>Constantine</PERSON> to transplant the warlike colony from the <NORP>Italian</NORP> provinces to the Persian war; and the son of <PERSON>Melo</PERSON> distributed among the chiefs the gold and manufactures of Greece, as the first-fruits of the <NORP>Imperial</NORP> bounty.
 But his arts were baffled by the sense and spirit of the conquerors of Apulia: his gifts, or at least his proposals, were rejected; and they unanimously refused to relinquish their possessions and their hopes for the distant prospect of <NORP>Asiatic</NORP> fortune.
 League of the Pope and the <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> empires, A.
D.
 1049-1054.
 After the means of persuasion had failed, <PERSON>Argyrus</PERSON> resolved to compel or to destroy: the <NORP>Latin</NORP> powers were solicited against the common enemy; and an offensive alliance was formed of the pope and the <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> emperors of the <LOC>East</LOC> and West.
 The throne of St.
 Peter was occupied by <PERSON>Leo</PERSON> the Ninth, a simple saint, (32) of a temper most apt to deceive himself and the world, and whose venerable character would consecrate with the name of piety the measures least compatible with the practice of religion.
 His humanity was affected by the complaints, perhaps the calumnies, of an injured people: the impious <NORP>Normans</NORP> had interrupted the payment of tithes; and the temporal sword might be lawfully unsheathed against the sacrilegious robbers, who were deaf to the censures of the church.
 As a <NORP>German</NORP> of noble birth and royal kindred, <PERSON>Leo</PERSON> had free access to the court and confidence of the emperor <PERSON>Henry</PERSON> the Third; and in search of arms and allies, his ardent zeal transported him from <GPE>Apulia</GPE> to Saxony, from the <LOC>Elbe</LOC> to the Tyber.
 During these hostile preparations, <PERSON>Argyrus</PERSON> indulged himself in the use of secret and guilty weapons: a crowd of <NORP>Normans</NORP> became the victims of public or private revenge; A.
D.
 1051and the valiant <PERSON>Drogo</PERSON> was murdered in a church.
 But his spirit survived in his brother Humphrey, the <ORDINAL>third</ORDINAL> count of Apulia.
 The assassins were chastised; and the son of Melo, overthrown and wounded, was driven from the field, to hide his shame behind the walls of Bari, and to await the tardy succour of his allies.
 Expedition of pope <PERSON>Leo</PERSON> IX.
 Against the Normans, A.
D.

 But the power of <PERSON>Constantine</PERSON> was distracted by a <NORP>Turkish</NORP> war; the mind of <PERSON>Henry</PERSON> was feeble and irresolute; and the pope, instead of repassing the <LOC>Alps</LOC> with a <NORP>German</NORP> army, was accompanied only by a guard of <CARDINAL>seven</CARDINAL> hundred <NORP>Swabians</NORP> and some volunteers of Lorraine.
 In his long progress from <GPE>Mantua</GPE> to Beneventum, a vile and promiscuous multitude of <NORP>Italians</NORP> was enlisted under the holy standard: (33) the priest and the robber slept in the same tent; the pikes and crosses were intermingled in the front; and the martial saint repeated the lessons of his youth in the order of march, of encampment, and of combat.
 The <NORP>Normans</NORP> of <GPE>Apulia</GPE> could muster in the field no more than <CARDINAL>three</CARDINAL> thousand horse, with a handful of infantry: the defection of the natives intercepted their provisions and retreat; and their spirit, incapable of fear, was chilled for a moment by superstitious awe.
 On the hostile approach of Leo, they knelt without disgrace or reluctance before their spiritual father.
 But the pope was inexorable; his lofty <NORP>Germans</NORP> affected to deride the diminutive stature of their adversaries; and the <NORP>Normans</NORP> were informed that death or exile was their only alternative.
 Flight they disdained, and, as many of them had been <CARDINAL>three</CARDINAL> days without tasting food, they embraced the assurance of a more easy and honourable death.
 They climbed the hill of Civitella, descended into the plain, and charged in <CARDINAL>three</CARDINAL> divisions the army of the pope.
 His defeat and captivity, June 18.
 On the left, and in the centre, <PERSON>Richard</PERSON> count of Aversa, and <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> the famous Guiscard, attacked, broke, routed, and pursued the <NORP>Italian</NORP> multitudes, who fought without discipline, and fled without shame.
 A harder trial was reserved for the valour of Count Humphrey, who led the cavalry of the right wing.
 The <NORP>Germans</NORP> (34) have been described as unskillful in the management of the horse and the lance, but on foot they formed a strong and impenetrable phalanx; and neither man, nor steed, nor armour, could resist the weight of their long and two-handed swords.
 After a severe conflict, they were encompassed by the squadrons returning from the pursuit; and died in the ranks with the esteem of their foes, and the satisfaction of revenge.
 The gates of <PERSON>Civitella</PERSON> were shut against the flying pope, and he was overtaken by the pious conquerors, who kissed his feet, to implore his blessing and the absolution of their sinful victory.
 The soldiers beheld in their enemy and captive the vicar of Christ; and, though we may suppose the policy of the chiefs, it is probable that they were infected by the popular superstition.
 In the calm of retirement, the well-meaning pope deplored the effusion of <NORP>Christian</NORP> blood, which must be imputed to his account: he felt, that he had been the author of sin and scandal; and as his undertaking had failed, the indecency of his military character was universally condemned.
 (35) With these dispositions, he listened to the offers of a beneficial treaty; deserted an alliance which he had preached as the cause of God; and ratified the past and future conquests of the Normans.
 Origin of the papal investitures to the Normans.
 By whatever hands they had been usurped, the provinces of <GPE>Apulia</GPE> and <GPE>Calabria</GPE> were a part of the donation of <PERSON>Constantine</PERSON> and the patrimony of St.
 Peter: the grant and the acceptance confirmed the mutual claims of the pontiff and the adventurers.
 They promised to support each other with spiritual and temporal arms; a tribute or quitrent of <CARDINAL>twelve</CARDINAL> pence was afterwards stipulated for every ploughland; and since this memorable transaction, the kingdom of <GPE>Naples</GPE> has remained above <CARDINAL>seven</CARDINAL> hundred <DATE>years</DATE> a fief of the Holy See.
 (36) Birth and character of <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> Guiscard, A.
D.

 The pedigree of <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> of <PERSON>Guiscard</PERSON> (37) is variously deduced from the peasants and the dukes of Normandy: from the peasants, by the pride and ignorance of a <NORP>Grecian</NORP> princess; (38) from the dukes, by the ignorance and flattery of the <NORP>Italian</NORP> subjects.
 (39) His genuine descent may be ascribed to the <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> or middle order of private nobility.
 (40) He sprang from a race of valvassors or bannerets, of the diocese of Coutances, in the Lower Normandy: the castle of <GPE>Hauteville</GPE> was their honourable seat: his father <PERSON>Tancred</PERSON> was conspicuous in the court and army of the duke; and his military service was furnished by <CARDINAL>ten</CARDINAL> soldiers or knights.
 <CARDINAL>Two</CARDINAL> marriages, of a rank not unworthy of his own, made him the father of <CARDINAL>twelve</CARDINAL> sons, who were educated at home by the impartial tenderness of his <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> wife.
 But a narrow patrimony was insufficient for this numerous and daring progeny; they saw around the neighbourhood the mischiefs of poverty and discord, and resolved to seek in foreign wars a more glorious inheritance.
 <CARDINAL>Two</CARDINAL> only remained to perpetuate the race, and cherish their father's age: their <CARDINAL>ten</CARDINAL> brothers, as they successfully attained the vigour of manhood, departed from the castle, passed the Alps, and joined the <NORP>Apulian</NORP> camp of the Normans.
 The elder were prompted by native spirit; their success encouraged their younger brethren, and the <CARDINAL>three</CARDINAL> <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> in seniority, William, Drogo, and Humphrey, deserved to be the chiefs of their nation and the founders of the new republic.
 <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> was the eldest of the <CARDINAL>seven</CARDINAL> sons of the <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> marriage; and even the reluctant praise of his foes has endowed him with the heroic qualities of a soldier and a statesman.
 His lofty stature surpassed the tallest of his army: his limbs were cast in the true proportion of strength and gracefulness; and to the decline of life, he maintained the patient vigour of health and the commanding dignity of his form.
 His complexion was ruddy, his shoulders were broad, his hair and beard were long and of a flaxen colour, his eyes sparkled with fire, and his voice, like that of Achilles, could impress obedience and terror amidst the tumult of battle.
 In the ruder ages of chivalry, such qualifications are not below the notice of the poet or historians: they may observe that Robert, at once, and with equal dexterity, could wield in the right hand his sword, his lance in the left; that in the battle of <PERSON>Civitella</PERSON> he was thrice unhorsed; and that in the close of that memorable day he was adjudged to have borne away the prize of valour from the warriors of the <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> armies.
 (41) His boundless ambition was founded on the consciousness of superior worth: in the pursuit of greatness, he was never arrested by the scruples of justice, and seldom moved by the feelings of humanity: though not insensible of fame, the choice of open or clandestine means was determined only by his present advantage.
 The surname of <PERSON>Guiscard</PERSON> (42) was applied to this master of political wisdom, which is too often confounded with the practice of dissimulation and deceit; and <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> is praised by the <NORP>Apulian</NORP> poet for excelling the cunning of <PERSON>Ulysses</PERSON> and the eloquence of Cicero.
 Yet these arts were disguised by an appearance of military frankness: in his highest fortune, he was accessible and courteous to his fellow-soldiers; and while he indulged the prejudices of his new subjects, he affected in his dress and manners to maintain the ancient fashion of his country.
 He grasped with a rapacious, that he might distribute with a liberal, hand: his primitive indigence had taught the habits of frugality; the gain of a merchant was not below his attention; and his prisoners were tortured with slow and unfeeling cruelty, to force a discovery of their secret treasure.
 According to the Greeks, he departed from <GPE>Normandy</GPE> with only <CARDINAL>five</CARDINAL> followers on horseback and <CARDINAL>thirty</CARDINAL> on foot; yet even this allowance appears too bountiful: the <ORDINAL>sixth</ORDINAL> son of <PERSON>Tancred</PERSON> of <GPE>Hauteville</GPE> passed the <LOC>Alps</LOC> as a pilgrim; and his <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> military band was levied among the adventurers of Italy.

 To surprise a castle or a convent, to ensnare a wealthy citizen, to plunder the adjacent villages for necessary food, were the obscure labours which formed and exercised the powers of his mind and body.
 The volunteers of <GPE>Normandy</GPE> adhered to his standard; and, under his command, the peasants of <GPE>Calabria</GPE> assumed the name and character of Normans.

 As the genius of <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> expanded with his fortune, he awakened the jealousy of his elder brother, by whom, in a transient quarrel, his life was threatened and his liberty restrained.

 School of Salerno.
 I.
 Of the learned faculties, jurisprudence implies the previous establishment of laws and property; and theology may perhaps be superseded by the full light of religion and reason.
 But the savage and the sage must alike implore the assistance of physic; and, if our diseases are inflamed by luxury, the mischiefs of blows and wounds would be more frequent in the ruder ages of society.
 The treasures of <NORP>Grecian</NORP> medicine had been communicated to the <NORP>Arabian</NORP> colonies of Africa, Spain, and Sicily; and in the intercourse of peace and war, a spark of knowledge had been kindled and cherished at Salerno, an illustrious city, in which the men were honest and the women beautiful.
 (49) A school, the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> that arose in the darkness of Europe, was consecrated to the healing art: the conscience of monks and bishops was reconciled to that salutary and lucrative profession; and a crowd of patients, of the most eminent rank, and most distant climates, invited or visited the physicians of Salerno.
 They were protected by the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> conquerors; and Guiscard, though bred in arms, could discern the merit and value of a philosopher.
 After a pilgrimage of thirty-nine years, Constantine, an <NORP>African</NORP> Christian, returned from Bagdad, a master of the language and learning of the Arabians; and <GPE>Salerno</GPE> was enriched by the practice, the lessons, and the writings of the pupil of Avicenna.
 The school of medicine has long slept in the name of a university; but her precepts are abridged in a string of aphorisms, bound together in the <NORP>Leonine</NORP> verses, or <NORP>Latin</NORP> rhymes, of the <ORDINAL>twelfth</ORDINAL> century.
 (50) Trade of Amalphi.
 II.
 Seven miles to the west of Salerno, and <CARDINAL>thirty</CARDINAL> to the south of Naples, the obscure town of <ORG>Amalphi</ORG> displayed the power and rewards of industry.
 The land, however fertile, was of narrow extent; but the sea was accessible and open: the inhabitants <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> assumed the office of supplying the western world with the manufactures and productions of the East; and this useful traffic was the source of their opulence and freedom.
 The government was popular, under the administration of a duke and the supremacy of the <NORP>Greek</NORP> emperor.
 Fifty thousand citizens were numbered in the walls of Amalphi; nor was any city more abundantly provided with gold, silver, and the objects of precious luxury.
 The mariners who swarmed in her port, excelled in the theory and practice of navigation and astronomy: and the discovery of the compass, which has opened the globe, is owing to their ingenuity or good fortune.
 Their trade was extended to the coasts, or at least to the commodities, of Africa, Arabia, and India: and their settlements in Constantinople, Antioch, Jerusalem, and Alexandria, acquired the privileges of independent colonies.
 (51) After <CARDINAL>three</CARDINAL> hundred <DATE>years</DATE> of prosperity, <ORG>Amalphi</ORG> was oppressed by the arms of the Normans, and sacked by the jealousy of Pisa; but the poverty of <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> thousand fisherman is yet dignified by the remains of an arsenal, a cathedral, and the palaces of royal merchants.

 Siege of Durazzo, A.
D.

 The army and the march of the emperor Alexius, April-September.
 While the <NORP>Roman</NORP> empire was attacked by the <NORP>Turks</NORP> in the East, east, and the <NORP>Normans</NORP> in the West, the aged successor of <PERSON>Michael</PERSON> surrendered the sceptre to the hands of Alexius, an illustrious captain, and the founder of the <NORP>Comnenian</NORP> dynasty.

 "You behold," said he, "your danger: it is urgent and inevitable.

 Duke of Apulia, A.

 On the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> intelligence of his premature death, <PERSON>Roger</PERSON> sailed from <GPE>Palermo</GPE> with <CARDINAL>seven</CARDINAL> galleys, cast anchor in the Bay of Salerno, received, after <CARDINAL>ten</CARDINAL> days' negotiation, an oath of fidelity from the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> capital, commanded the submission of the barons, and extorted a legal investiture from the reluctant popes, who could not long endure either the friendship or enmity of a powerful vassal.
 The sacred spot of <PERSON>Benevento</PERSON> was respectfully spared, as the patrimony of St.

 His conquests in Africa, A.
D.
 1122-1152.
 As a penance for his impious war against the successor of St.
 Peter, that monarch might have promised to display the banner of the cross, and he accomplished with ardour a vow so propitious to his interest and revenge.
 The recent injuries of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> might provoke a just retaliation on the heads of the Saracens: the Normans, whose blood had been mingled with so many subject streams, were encouraged to remember and emulate the naval trophies of their fathers, and in the maturity of their strength they contended with the decline of an <NORP>African</NORP> power.
 When the <NORP>Fatimite</NORP> caliph departed for the conquest of Egypt, he rewarded the real merit and apparent fidelity of his servant <PERSON>Joseph</PERSON> with a gift of his royal mantle, and <CARDINAL>forty</CARDINAL> <NORP>Arabian</NORP> horses, his palace with its sumptuous furniture, and the government of the kingdoms of <GPE>Tunis</GPE> and Algiers.
 The Zeirides, (103) the descendants of Joseph, forgot their allegiance and gratitude to a distant benefactor, grasped and abused the fruits of prosperity; and after running the little course of an <NORP>Oriental</NORP> dynasty, were now fainting in their own weakness.
 On the side of the land, they were pressed by the Almohades, the fanatic princes of Morocco, while the sea-coast was open to the enterprises of the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> and Franks, who, before the close of the eleventh century, had extorted a ransom of <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> hundred thousand pieces of gold.
 By the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> arms of Roger, the island or rock of Malta, which has been since ennobled by a military and religious colony, was inseparably annexed to the crown of Sicily.
 Tripoli, (104) a strong and maritime city, was the next object of his attack; and the slaughter of the males, the captivity of the females, might be justified by the frequent practice of the <NORP>Moslems</NORP> themselves.
 The capital of the <GPE>Zeirides</GPE> was named <LOC>Africa</LOC> from the country, and <PERSON>Mahadia</PERSON> (105) from the <NORP>Arabian</NORP> founder: it is strongly built on a neck of land, but the imperfection of the harbour is not compensated by the fertility of the adjacent plain.

 (107) After his death, that sword was broken; and these transmarine possessions were neglected, evacuated, or lost, under the troubled reign of his successor.
 (108) The triumphs of <PERSON>Scipio</PERSON> and <PERSON>Belisarius</PERSON> have proved, that the <NORP>African</NORP> continent is neither inaccessible nor invincible; yet the great princes and powers of <NORP>Christendom</NORP> have repeatedly failed in their armaments against the Moors, who may still glory in the easy conquest and long servitude of Spain.
 His invasion of Greece, A.
D.

 Since the decease of <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> Guiscard, the <NORP>Normans</NORP> had relinquished, above sixty years, their hostile designs against the empire of the East.
 The policy of <PERSON>Roger</PERSON> solicited a public and private union with the <NORP>Greek</NORP> princes, whose alliance would dignify his regal character: he demanded in marriage a daughter of the <NORP>Comnenian</NORP> family, and the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> steps of the treaty seemed to promise a favourable event.
 But the contemptuous treatment of his ambassadors exasperated the vanity of the new monarch; and the insolence of the <NORP>Byzantine</NORP> court was expiated, according to the laws of nations, by the sufferings of a guiltless people.
 (109) With the fleet of <CARDINAL>seventy</CARDINAL> galleys, George, the admiral of Sicily, appeared before Corfu; and both the island and city were delivered into his hands by the disaffected inhabitants, who had yet to learn that a siege is still more calamitous than a tribute.
 In this invasion, of some moment in the annals of commerce, the <NORP>Normans</NORP> spread themselves by sea, and over the provinces of Greece; and the venerable age of Athens, Thebes, and Corinth, was violated by rapine and cruelty.
 Of the wrongs of Athens, no memorial remains.
 The ancient walls, which encompassed, without guarding, the opulence of Thebes, were scaled by the <NORP>Latin</NORP> Christians; but their sole use of the gospel was to sanctify an oath, that the lawful owners had not secreted any relic of their inheritance or industry.
 On the approach of the Normans, the lower town of <GPE>Corinth</GPE> was evacuated; the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> retired to the citadel, which was seated on a lofty eminence, abundantly watered by the classic fountain of Pirene; an impregnable fortress, if the want of courage could be balanced by any advantages of art or nature.
 As soon as the besiegers had surmounted the labor (their sole labor) of climbing the hill, their general, from the commanding eminence, admired his own victory, and testified his gratitude to Heaven, by tearing from the altar the precious image of Theodore, the tutelary saint.
 The silk weavers of both sexes, whom <PERSON>George</PERSON> transported to Sicily, composed the most valuable part of the spoil; and in comparing the skilful industry of the mechanic with the sloth and cowardice of the soldier, he was heard to exclaim that the distaff and loom were the only weapons which the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> were capable of using.
 His admiral delivers <PERSON>LouisVII</PERSON> of France.

 This playful outrage of the pirates of Sicily, who had surprised an unguarded moment, <PERSON>Manuel</PERSON> affected to despise, while his martial spirit, and the forces of the empire, were awakened to revenge.

 He reduces <GPE>Apulia</GPE> and Calabria, A.

 (118) Failure of his designs.
 But these <NORP>Italian</NORP> conquests, this universal reign, soon escaped from the hand of the <NORP>Greek</NORP> emperor.

 (121) By his own avarice, or the complaints of his subjects, the <NORP>Greek</NORP> emperor was provoked to arrest the persons, and confiscate the effects, of the <NORP>Venetian</NORP> merchants.

 The lieutenant of <PERSON>Manuel</PERSON> had informed his sovereign that he was strong enough to quell any domestic revolt of <GPE>Apulia</GPE> and Calabria; but that his forces were inadequate to resist the impending attack of the king of Sicily.

 Last war of the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> and Normans, A.
D.
 1185.
 The <NORP>Latin</NORP> historians (124) expatiate on the rapid progress of the <CARDINAL>four</CARDINAL> counts who invaded <GPE>Romania</GPE> with a fleet and army, and reduced many castles and cities to the obedience of the king of Sicily.
 The <NORP>Greeks</NORP> (125) accuse and magnify the wanton and sacrilegious cruelties that were perpetrated in the sack of Thessalonica, the <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> city of the empire.
 The former deplore the fate of those invincible but unsuspecting warriors who were destroyed by the arts of a vanquished foe.
 The latter applaud, in songs of triumph, the repeated victories of their countrymen on the Sea of Marmora or Propontis, on the banks of the Strymon, and under the walls of Durazzo.
 A revolution which punished the crimes of Andronicus, had united against the <PERSON>Franks</PERSON> the zeal and courage of the successful insurgents: <CARDINAL>ten</CARDINAL> thousand were slain in battle, and Isaac Angelus, the new emperor, might indulge his vanity or vengeance in the treatment of <CARDINAL>four</CARDINAL> thousand captives.
 Such was the event of the last contest between the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> and Normans: before the expiration of <CARDINAL>twenty</CARDINAL> years, the rival nations were lost or degraded in foreign servitude; and the successors of <PERSON>Constantine</PERSON> did not long survive to insult the fall of the <NORP>Sicilian</NORP> monarchy.
 <PERSON>William</PERSON> I.
 the Bad king of Sicily, A.

26 -A.

 The sceptre of <PERSON>Roger</PERSON> successively devolved to his son and grandson: they might be confounded under the name of William: they are strongly discriminated by the epithets of the bad and the good; but these epithets, which appear to describe the perfection of vice and virtue, cannot strictly be applied to either of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> princes.
 When he was roused to arms by danger and shame, the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> <PERSON>William</PERSON> did not degenerate from the valour of his race; but his temper was slothful; his manners were dissolute; his passions headstrong and mischievous; and the monarch is responsible, not only for his personal vices, but for those of Majo, the great admiral, who abused the confidence, and conspired against the life, of his benefactor.
 From the <NORP>Arabian</NORP> conquest, <GPE>Sicily</GPE> had imbibed a deep tincture of <NORP>Oriental</NORP> manners; the despotism, the pomp, and even the harem, of a sultan; and a <NORP>Christian</NORP> people was oppressed and insulted by the ascendant of the eunuchs, who openly professed, or secretly cherished, the religion of Mahomet.
 An eloquent historian of the times (126) has delineated the misfortunes of his country: (127) the ambition and fall of the ungrateful Majo; the revolt and punishment of his assassins; the imprisonment and deliverance of the king himself; the private feuds that arose from the public confusion; and the various forms of calamity and discord which afflicted Palermo, the island, and the continent, during the reign of <PERSON>William</PERSON> the First, and the minority of his son.
 <PERSON>William</PERSON> II.
 the Good, A.
D.
 1166, <DATE>May</DATE> <CARDINAL>7</CARDINAL> -A.
D.

 The youth, innocence, and beauty of <PERSON>William</PERSON> the Second, (128) endeared him to the nation: the factions were reconciled; the laws were revived; and from the manhood to the premature death of that amiable prince, <GPE>Sicily</GPE> enjoyed a short season of peace, justice, and happiness, whose value was enhanced by the remembrance of the past and the dread of futurity.
 The legitimate male posterity of <PERSON>Tancred</PERSON> of <GPE>Hauteville</GPE> was extinct in the person of the <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> William; but his aunt, the daughter of Roger, had married the most powerful prince of the age; and <PERSON>Henry</PERSON> the Sixth, the son of <PERSON>Frederic</PERSON> Barbarossa, descended from the <LOC>Alps</LOC> to claim the <NORP>Imperial</NORP> crown and the inheritance of his wife.
 Against the unanimous wish of a free people, this inheritance could only be acquired by arms; and I am pleased to transcribe the style and sense of the historian Falcandus, who writes at the moment, and on the spot, with the feelings of a patriot, and the prophetic eye of a statesman.
 Lamentation of the historian Falcandus.
 "Constantia, the daughter of Sicily, nursed from her cradle in the pleasures and plenty, and educated in the arts and manners, of this fortunate isle, departed long since to enrich the <NORP>Barbarians</NORP> with our treasures, and now returns, with her savage allies, to contaminate the beauties of her venerable parent.
 Already I behold the swarms of angry Barbarians: our opulent cities, the places flourishing in a long peace, are shaken with fear, desolated by slaughter, consumed by rapine, and polluted by intemperance and lust.
 I see the massacre or captivity of our citizens, the rapes of our virgins and matrons.
 (129) In this extremity (he interrogates a friend) how must the <NORP>Sicilians</NORP> act? By the unanimous election of a king of valour and experience, <GPE>Sicily</GPE> and <GPE>Calabria</GPE> might yet be preserved; (130) for in the levity of the Apulians, ever eager for new revolutions, I can repose neither confidence nor hope.
 (131) Should <GPE>Calabria</GPE> be lost, the lofty towers, the numerous youth, and the naval strength, of Messina, (132) might guard the passage against a foreign invader.
 If the savage <NORP>Germans</NORP> coalesce with the pirates of Messina; if they destroy with fire the fruitful region, so often wasted by the fires of Mount Aetna, (133) what resource will be left for the interior parts of the island, these noble cities which should never be violated by the hostile footsteps of a Barbarian? (134) <PERSON>Catana</PERSON> has again been overwhelmed by an earthquake: the ancient virtue of <GPE>Syracuse</GPE> expires in poverty and solitude; (135) but <GPE>Palermo</GPE> is still crowned with a diadem, and her triple walls enclose the active multitudes of <NORP>Christians</NORP> and Saracens.
 If the <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> nations, under <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> king, can unite for their common safety, they may rush on the <NORP>Barbarians</NORP> with invincible arms.
 But if the Saracens, fatigued by a repetition of injuries, should now retire and rebel; if they should occupy the castles of the mountains and sea-coast, the unfortunate Christians, exposed to a double attack, and placed as it were between the hammer and the anvil, must resign themselves to hopeless and inevitable servitude.
" (136) We must not forget, that a priest here prefers his country to his religion; and that the Moslems, whose alliance he seeks, were still numerous and powerful in the state of Sicily.
 Conquest of the kingdom of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> by the emperor <PERSON>Henry</PERSON> VI.
 A.
D.
 1194.
 The hopes, or at least the wishes, of <PERSON>Falcandus</PERSON> were at <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> gratified by the free and unanimous election of Tancred, the grandson of the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> king, whose birth was illegitimate, but whose civil and military virtues shone without a blemish.
 During <CARDINAL>four</CARDINAL> years, the term of his life and reign, he stood in arms on the farthest verge of the <NORP>Apulian</NORP> frontier, against the powers of Germany; and the restitution of a royal captive, of <PERSON>Constantia</PERSON> herself, without injury or ransom, may appear to surpass the most liberal measure of policy or reason.
 After his decease, the kingdom of his widow and infant son fell without a struggle; and <PERSON>Henry</PERSON> pursued his victorious march from <GPE>Capua</GPE> to Palermo.
 The political balance of <GPE>Italy</GPE> was destroyed by his success; and if the pope and the free cities had consulted their obvious and real interest, they would have combined the powers of earth and heaven to prevent the dangerous union of the <NORP>German</NORP> empire with the kingdom of Sicily.
 But the subtle policy, for which the <FAC>Vatican</FAC> has so often been praised or arraigned, was on this occasion blind and inactive; and if it were true that <PERSON>Celestine</PERSON> the <ORDINAL>Third</ORDINAL> had kicked away the <NORP>Imperial</NORP> crown from the head of the prostrate Henry, (137) such an act of impotent pride could serve only to cancel an obligation and provoke an enemy.
 The Genoese, who enjoyed a beneficial trade and establishment in Sicily, listened to the promise of his boundless gratitude and speedy departure: (138) their fleet commanded the straits of Messina, and opened the harbour of Palermo; and the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> act of his government was to abolish the privileges, and to seize the property, of these imprudent allies.
 The last hope of <PERSON>Falcandus</PERSON> was defeated by the discord of the <NORP>Christians</NORP> and Mahometans: they fought in the capital; several <CARDINAL>thousands</CARDINAL> of the latter were slain; but their surviving brethren fortified the mountains, and disturbed above <CARDINAL>thirty</CARDINAL> <DATE>years</DATE> the peace of the island.
 By the policy of <PERSON>Frederic</PERSON> the Second, sixty thousand <NORP>Saracens</NORP> were transplanted to <GPE>Nocera</GPE> in Apulia.
 In their wars against the <NORP>Roman</NORP> church, the emperor and his son <PERSON>Mainfroy</PERSON> were strengthened and disgraced by the service of the enemies of Christ; and this national colony maintained their religion and manners in the heart of Italy, till they were extirpated, at the end of the thirteenth century, by the zeal and revenge of the house of Anjou.
 (139) All the calamities which the prophetic orator had deplored were surpassed by the cruelty and avarice of the <NORP>German</NORP> conqueror.
 He violated the royal sepulchres and explored the secret treasures of the palace, Palermo, and the whole kingdom: the pearls and jewels, however precious, might be easily removed; but <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> hundred and sixty horses were laden with the gold and silver of Sicily.
 (140) The young king, his mother and sisters, and the nobles of both sexes, were separately confined in the fortresses of the Alps; and, on the slightest rumour of rebellion, the captives were deprived of life, of their eyes, or of the hope of posterity.
 <PERSON>Constantia</PERSON> herself was touched with sympathy for the miseries of her country; and the heiress of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> line might struggle to check her despotic husband, and to save the patrimony of her new-born son, of an emperor so famous in the next age under the name of <PERSON>Frederic</PERSON> the Second.
 Final extinction of the Normans, A.
D.
 1204.
 Ten <DATE>years</DATE> after this revolution, the <NORP>French</NORP> monarchs annexed to their crown the duchy of Normandy: the sceptre of her ancient dukes had been transmitted, by a granddaughter of <PERSON>William</PERSON> the Conqueror, to the house of Plantagenet; and the adventurous Normans, who had raised so many trophies in France, England, and Ireland, in Apulia, Sicily, and the East, were lost, either in victory or servitude, among the vanquished nations.
