 School of Salerno.
 I.
 Of the learned faculties, jurisprudence implies the previous establishment of laws and property; and theology may perhaps be superseded by the full light of religion and reason.
 But the savage and the sage must alike implore the assistance of physic; and, if our diseases are inflamed by luxury, the mischiefs of blows and wounds would be more frequent in the ruder ages of society.
 The treasures of <NORP>Grecian</NORP> medicine had been communicated to the <NORP>Arabian</NORP> colonies of Africa, Spain, and Sicily; and in the intercourse of peace and war, a spark of knowledge had been kindled and cherished at Salerno, an illustrious city, in which the men were honest and the women beautiful.
 (49) A school, the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> that arose in the darkness of Europe, was consecrated to the healing art: the conscience of monks and bishops was reconciled to that salutary and lucrative profession; and a crowd of patients, of the most eminent rank, and most distant climates, invited or visited the physicians of Salerno.
 They were protected by the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> conquerors; and Guiscard, though bred in arms, could discern the merit and value of a philosopher.
 After a pilgrimage of thirty-nine years, Constantine, an <NORP>African</NORP> Christian, returned from Bagdad, a master of the language and learning of the Arabians; and <GPE>Salerno</GPE> was enriched by the practice, the lessons, and the writings of the pupil of Avicenna.
 The school of medicine has long slept in the name of a university; but her precepts are abridged in a string of aphorisms, bound together in the <NORP>Leonine</NORP> verses, or <NORP>Latin</NORP> rhymes, of the <ORDINAL>twelfth</ORDINAL> century.
 (50) Trade of Amalphi.
 II.
 Seven miles to the west of Salerno, and <CARDINAL>thirty</CARDINAL> to the south of Naples, the obscure town of <ORG>Amalphi</ORG> displayed the power and rewards of industry.
 The land, however fertile, was of narrow extent; but the sea was accessible and open: the inhabitants <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> assumed the office of supplying the western world with the manufactures and productions of the East; and this useful traffic was the source of their opulence and freedom.
 The government was popular, under the administration of a duke and the supremacy of the <NORP>Greek</NORP> emperor.
 Fifty thousand citizens were numbered in the walls of Amalphi; nor was any city more abundantly provided with gold, silver, and the objects of precious luxury.
 The mariners who swarmed in her port, excelled in the theory and practice of navigation and astronomy: and the discovery of the compass, which has opened the globe, is owing to their ingenuity or good fortune.
 Their trade was extended to the coasts, or at least to the commodities, of Africa, Arabia, and India: and their settlements in Constantinople, Antioch, Jerusalem, and Alexandria, acquired the privileges of independent colonies.
 (51) After <CARDINAL>three</CARDINAL> hundred <DATE>years</DATE> of prosperity, <ORG>Amalphi</ORG> was oppressed by the arms of the Normans, and sacked by the jealousy of Pisa; but the poverty of <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> thousand fisherman is yet dignified by the remains of an arsenal, a cathedral, and the palaces of royal merchants.
 Conquest of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> by count Roger, A.
D.
 1060-1090.
 Roger, the <ORDINAL>twelfth</ORDINAL> and last of the sons of Tancred, had been long detained in <GPE>Normandy</GPE> by his own and his father' age.
 He accepted the welcome summons; hastened to the <NORP>Apulian</NORP> camp; and deserved at <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> the esteem, and afterwards the envy, of his elder brother.
 Their valour and ambition were equal; but the youth, the beauty, the elegant manners, of <PERSON>Roger</PERSON> engaged the disinterested love of the soldiers and people.
 So scanty was his allowance for himself and <CARDINAL>forty</CARDINAL> followers, that he descended from conquest to robbery, and from robbery to domestic theft; and so loose were the notions of property, that, by his own historian, at his special command, he is accused of stealing horses from a stable at Melphi.
 (52) His spirit emerged from poverty and disgrace: from these base practices he rose to the merit and glory of a holy war; and the invasion of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> was seconded by the zeal and policy of his brother Guiscard.
 After the retreat of the Greeks, the idolaters, a most audacious reproach of the Catholics, had retrieved their losses and possessions; but the deliverance of the island, so vainly undertaken by the forces of the <NORP>Eastern</NORP> empire, was achieved by a small and private band of adventurers.
 (53) In the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> attempt, <PERSON>Roger</PERSON> braved, in an open boat, the real and fabulous dangers of <PRODUCT>Scylla</PRODUCT> and Charybdis; landed with only sixty soldiers on a hostile shore; drove the <NORP>Saracens</NORP> to the gates of <GPE>Messina</GPE> and safely returned with the spoils of the adjacent country.
 In the fortress of Trani, his active and patient courage were equally conspicuous.
 In his old age he related with pleasure, that, by the distress of the siege, himself, and the countess his wife, had been reduced to a single cloak or mantle, which they wore alternately; that in a sally his horse had been slain, and he was dragged away by the Saracens; but that he owed his rescue to his good sword, and had retreated with his saddle on his back, lest the meanest trophy might be left in the hands of the miscreants.
 In the siege of Trani, <CARDINAL>three</CARDINAL> hundred <NORP>Normans</NORP> withstood and repulsed the forces of the island.
 In the field of Ceramio, <CARDINAL>fifty</CARDINAL> thousand horse and foot were overthrown by <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> hundred and <CARDINAL>thirty-six</CARDINAL> <NORP>Christian</NORP> soldiers, without reckoning St.

 The captive banners, with <CARDINAL>four</CARDINAL> camels, were reserved for the successor of St.

 These insufficient numbers of the <NORP>Normans</NORP> most probably denote their knights, the soldiers of honorable and equestrian rank, each of whom was attended by <CARDINAL>five</CARDINAL> or <CARDINAL>six</CARDINAL> followers in the field; (54) yet, with the aid of this interpretation, and after every fair allowance on the side of valour, arms, and reputation, the discomfiture of so many myriads will reduce the prudent reader to the alternative of a miracle or a fable.
 The <NORP>Arabs</NORP> of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> derived a frequent and powerful succour from their countrymen of Africa: in the siege of Palermo, the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> cavalry was assisted by the galleys of Pisa; and, in the hour of action, the envy of the <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> brothers was sublimed to a generous and invincible emulation.
 After a war of <CARDINAL>thirty</CARDINAL> years, (55) Roger, with the title of great count, obtained the sovereignty of the largest and most fruitful island of the Mediterranean; and his administration displays a liberal and enlightened mind, above the limits of his age and education.
 The <NORP>Moslems</NORP> were maintained in the free enjoyment of their religion and property: (56) a philosopher and physician of Mazara, of the race of Mahomet, harangued the conqueror, and was invited to court; his geography of the <CARDINAL>seven</CARDINAL> climates was translated into Latin; and Roger, after a diligent perusal, preferred the work of the <NORP>Arabian</NORP> to the writings of the <NORP>Grecian</NORP> Ptolemy.
 (57) A remnant of <NORP>Christian</NORP> natives had promoted the success of the Normans: they were rewarded by the triumph of the cross.
 The island was restored to the jurisdiction of the <NORP>Roman</NORP> pontiff; new bishops were planted in the principal cities; and the clergy was satisfied by a liberal endowment of churches and monasteries.
 Yet the <NORP>Catholic</NORP> hero asserted the rights of the civil magistrate.
 Instead of resigning the investiture of benefices, he dexterously applied to his own profit the papal claims: the supremacy of the crown was secured and enlarged, by the singular bull, which declares the princes of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> hereditary and perpetual legates of the Holy See.
 (58) <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> invades the <NORP>Eastern</NORP> empire, A.
D.
 1081.
 To <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> Guiscard, the conquest of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> was more glorious than beneficial: the possession of <GPE>Apulia</GPE> and <GPE>Calabria</GPE> was inadequate to his ambition; and he resolved to embrace or create the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> occasion of invading, perhaps of subduing, the <NORP>Roman</NORP> empire of the East.

 Siege of Durazzo, A.
D.
 1081, June 17.
 At the mouth of the <LOC>Adriatic</LOC> Gulf, the shores of <GPE>Italy</GPE> and <LOC>Epirus</LOC> incline towards each other.
 The space between <PRODUCT>Brundusium</PRODUCT> and Durazzo, the <NORP>Roman</NORP> passage, is no more than <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> hundred miles; (65) at the last station of Otranto, it is contracted to fifty; (66) and this narrow distance had suggested to <PERSON>Pyrrhus</PERSON> and <PERSON>Pompey</PERSON> the sublime or extravagant idea of a bridge.

 They passed and landed without perceiving an enemy; and this successful experiment displayed the neglect and decay of the naval power of the Greeks.
 The islands of <LOC>Epirus</LOC> and the maritime towns were subdued by the arms or the name of Robert, who led his fleet and army from <PERSON>Corfu</PERSON> (I use the modern appellation) to the siege of Durazzo.
 That city, the western key of the empire, was guarded by ancient renown, and recent fortifications, by <PERSON>George</PERSON> Palaeologus, a patrician, victorious in the <NORP>Oriental</NORP> wars, and a numerous garrison of <NORP>Albanians</NORP> and Macedonians, who, in every age, have maintained the character of soldiers.

 In the most propitious season of the year, as his fleet passed along the coast, a storm of wind and snow unexpectedly arose: the <LOC>Adriatic</LOC> was swelled by the raging blast of the south, and a new shipwreck confirmed the old infamy of the <NORP>Acroceraunian</NORP> rocks.
 (67) The sails, the masts, and the oars, were shattered or torn away; the sea and shore were covered with the fragments of vessels, with arms and dead bodies; and the greatest part of the provisions were either drowned or damaged.
 The ducal galley was laboriously rescued from the waves, and <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> halted <CARDINAL>seven</CARDINAL> days on the adjacent cape, to collect the relics of his loss, and revive the drooping spirits of his soldiers.
 The <NORP>Normans</NORP> were no longer the bold and experienced mariners who had explored the ocean from <LOC>Greenland</LOC> to Mount Atlas, and who smiled at the petty dangers of the Mediterranean.
 They had wept during the tempest; they were alarmed by the hostile approach of the Venetians, who had been solicited by the prayers and promises of the <NORP>Byzantine</NORP> court.
 The <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> day's action was not disadvantageous to Bohemond, a beardless youth, (68) who led the naval powers of his father.
 All night the galleys of the republic lay on their anchors in the form of a crescent; and the victory of the <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> day was decided by the dexterity of their evolutions, the station of their archers, the weight of their javelins, and the borrowed aid of the <NORP>Greek</NORP> fire.

 A seasonable relief was poured into Durazzo, and as soon as the besiegers had lost the command of the sea, the islands and maritime towns withdrew from the camp the supply of tribute and provision.
 That camp was soon afflicted with a pestilential disease; <CARDINAL>five</CARDINAL> hundred knights perished by an inglorious death; and the list of burials (if all could obtain a decent burial) amounted to <CARDINAL>ten</CARDINAL> thousand persons.
 Under these calamities, the mind of <PERSON>Guiscard</PERSON> alone was firm and invincible; and while he collected new forces from <GPE>Apulia</GPE> and Sicily, he battered, or scaled, or sapped, the walls of Durazzo.
 But his industry and valour were encountered by equal valour and more perfect industry.
 A movable turret, of a size and capacity to contain <CARDINAL>five</CARDINAL> hundred soldiers, had been rolled forwards to the foot of the rampart: but the descent of the door or drawbridge was checked by an enormous beam, and the wooden structure was constantly consumed by artificial flames.
 The army and the march of the emperor Alexius, April-September.
 While the <NORP>Roman</NORP> empire was attacked by the <NORP>Turks</NORP> in the East, east, and the <NORP>Normans</NORP> in the West, the aged successor of <PERSON>Michael</PERSON> surrendered the sceptre to the hands of Alexius, an illustrious captain, and the founder of the <NORP>Comnenian</NORP> dynasty.
 The princess Anne, his daughter and historian, observes, in her affected style, that even <PERSON>Hercules</PERSON> was unequal to a double combat; and, on this principle, she approves a hasty peace with the Turks, which allowed her father to undertake in person the relief of Durazzo.
 On his accession, <PERSON>Alexius</PERSON> found the camp without soldiers, and the treasury without money; yet such were the vigour and activity of his measures, that in <CARDINAL>six</CARDINAL> months he assembled an army of <CARDINAL>seventy</CARDINAL> thousand men, (69) and performed a march of <CARDINAL>five</CARDINAL> hundred miles.
 His troops were levied in <LOC>Europe</LOC> and Asia, from <LOC>Peloponnesus</LOC> to the Black Sea; his majesty was displayed in the silver arms and rich trappings of the companies of Horse-guards; and the emperor was attended by a train of nobles and princes, some of whom, in rapid succession, had been clothed with the purple, and were indulged by the lenity of the times in a life of affluence and dignity.
 Their youthful ardour might animate the multitude; but their love of pleasure and contempt of subordination were pregnant with disorder and mischief; and their importunate clamours for speedy and decisive action disconcerted the prudence of Alexius, who might have surrounded and starved the besieging army.
 The enumeration of provinces recalls a sad comparison of the past and present limits of the <NORP>Roman</NORP> world: the raw levies were drawn together in haste and terror; and the garrisons of Anatolia, or <LOC>Asia</LOC> Minor, had been purchased by the evacuation of the cities which were immediately occupied by the Turks.
 The strength of the <NORP>Greek</NORP> army consisted in the Varangians, the <NORP>Scandinavian</NORP> guards, whose numbers were recently augmented by a colony of exiles and volunteers from the British Island of Thule.
 Under the yoke of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> conqueror, the <NORP>Danes</NORP> and <LANGUAGE>English</LANGUAGE> were oppressed and united; a band of adventurous youths resolved to desert a land of slavery; the sea was open to their escape; and, in their long pilgrimage, they visited every coast that afforded any hope of liberty and revenge.
 They were entertained in the service of the <NORP>Greek</NORP> emperor; and their <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> station was in a new city on the <NORP>Asiatic</NORP> shore: but <PERSON>Alexius</PERSON> soon recalled them to the defence of his person and palace; and bequeathed to his successors the inheritance of their faith and valour.
 (70) The name of a <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> invader revived the memory of their wrongs: they marched with alacrity against the national foe, and panted to regain in <LOC>Epirus</LOC> the glory which they had lost in the battle of Hastings.
 The <NORP>Varangians</NORP> were supported by some companies of <PERSON>Franks</PERSON> or Latins; and the rebels, who had fled to <GPE>Constantinople</GPE> from the tyranny of Guiscard, were eager to signalize their zeal and gratify their revenge.
 In this emergency, the emperor had not disdained the impure aid of the <NORP>Paulicians</NORP> or <NORP>Manichaeans</NORP> of <LOC>Thrace</LOC> and Bulgaria; and these heretics united with the patience of martyrdom the spirit and discipline of active valour.
 (71) The treaty with the sultan had procured a supply of some thousand Turks; and the arrows of the <NORP>Scythian</NORP> horse were opposed to the lances of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> cavalry.
 On the report and distant prospect of these formidable numbers, <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> assembled a council of his principal officers.
 "You behold," said he, "your danger: it is urgent and inevitable.
 The hills are covered with arms and standards; and the emperor of the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> is accustomed to wars and triumphs.
 Obedience and union are our only safety; and I am ready to yield the command to a more worthy leader.
" The vote and acclamation even of his secret enemies, assured him, in that perilous moment, of their esteem and confidence; and the duke thus continued: "Let us trust in the rewards of victory, and deprive cowardice of the means of escape.
 Let us burn our vessels and our baggage, and give battle on this spot, as if it were the place of our nativity and our burial.
" The resolution was unanimously approved; and, without confining himself to his lines, <PERSON>Guiscard</PERSON> awaited in battle-array the nearer approach of the enemy.
 His rear was covered by a small river; his right wing extended to the sea; his left to the hills: nor was he conscious, perhaps, that on the same ground <PERSON>Caesar</PERSON> and <PERSON>Pompey</PERSON> had formerly disputed the empire of the world.
 (72) Battle of Durazzo, A.
D.
 1081, <DATE>October</DATE> 18.
 Against the advice of his wisest captains, <PERSON>Alexius</PERSON> resolved to risk the event of a general action, and exhorted the garrison of <ORG>Durazzo</ORG> to assist their own deliverance by a well-timed sally from the town.
 He marched in <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> columns to surprise the <NORP>Normans</NORP> before daybreak on <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> different sides: his light cavalry was scattered over the plain; the archers formed the <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> line; and the <NORP>Varangians</NORP> claimed the honours of the vanguard.
 In the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> onset, the battle-axes of the strangers made a deep and bloody impression on the army of Guiscard, which was now reduced to <CARDINAL>fifteen</CARDINAL> thousand men.
 The <NORP>Lombards</NORP> and <NORP>Calabrians</NORP> ignominiously turned their backs; they fled towards the river and the sea; but the bridge had been broken down to check the sally of the garrison, and the coast was lined with the <NORP>Venetian</NORP> galleys, who played their engines among the disorderly throng.

 (74) Her female voice was seconded by the more powerful voice and arm of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> duke, as calm in action as he was magnanimous in council: "Whither," he cried aloud, "whither do ye fly? Your enemy is implacable; and death is less grievous than servitude.

 (75) <PERSON>Alexius</PERSON> was not deficient in the duties of a soldier or a general; but he no sooner beheld the slaughter of the Varangians, and the flight of the Turks, than he despised his subjects, and despaired of his fortune.

 <ORG>Durazzo</ORG> taken, A.
D.
 1082, February 8.
 It is more than probable that <PERSON>Guiscard</PERSON> was not afflicted by the loss of a costly pageant, which had merited only the contempt and derision of the Greeks.

 Return of Robert, and the actions of Bohemond.
 Highly presuming that his person was sufficient for the public safety, he repassed the sea in a single brigantine, and left the remains of the army under the command of his son and the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> counts, exhorting <PERSON>Bohemond</PERSON> to respect the freedom of his peers, and the counts to obey the authority of their leader.

 Yet a just praise must not be refused to the fortitude and prudence of Alexius, who bravely struggled with the calamities of the times.

 The emperor <PERSON>Henry</PERSON> III invited by the Greeks, A.
D.
 1081.
 Of the <NORP>Latin</NORP> princes, the allies of <PERSON>Alexius</PERSON> and enemies of Robert, the most prompt and powerful was <PERSON>Henry</PERSON> the <ORDINAL>Third</ORDINAL> or Fourth, king of <GPE>Germany</GPE> and Italy, and future emperor of the West.
 The epistle of the <NORP>Greek</NORP> monarch (81) to his brother is filled with the warmest professions of friendship, and the most lively desire of strengthening their alliance by every public and private tie.

 His conquests in Africa, A.
D.

 As a penance for his impious war against the successor of St.

 After the reunion with Frederic, he spoke a more peremptory language, confirmed the acts of his predecessors, excommunicated the adherents of Manuel, and pronounced the final separation of the churches, or at least the empires, of <GPE>Constantinople</GPE> and Rome.
 (120) The free cities of <GPE>Lombardy</GPE> no longer remembered their foreign benefactor, and without preserving the friendship of Ancona, he soon incurred the enmity of Venice.
 (121) By his own avarice, or the complaints of his subjects, the <NORP>Greek</NORP> emperor was provoked to arrest the persons, and confiscate the effects, of the <NORP>Venetian</NORP> merchants.
 This violation of the public faith exasperated a free and commercial people: <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> hundred galleys were launched and armed in as many days; they swept the coasts of <LOC>Dalmatia</LOC> and Greece: but after some mutual wounds, the war was terminated by an agreement, inglorious to the empire, insufficient for the republic; and a complete vengeance of these and of fresh injuries was reserved for the succeeding generation.
 The lieutenant of <PERSON>Manuel</PERSON> had informed his sovereign that he was strong enough to quell any domestic revolt of <GPE>Apulia</GPE> and Calabria; but that his forces were inadequate to resist the impending attack of the king of Sicily.
 His prophecy was soon verified: the death of <PERSON>Palaeologus</PERSON> devolved the command on several chiefs, alike eminent in rank, alike defective in military talents; the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> were oppressed by land and sea; and a captive remnant that escaped the swords of the <NORP>Normans</NORP> and Saracens, abjured all future hostility against the person or dominions of their conqueror.
 (122) Yet the king of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> esteemed the courage and constancy of Manuel, who had landed a <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> army on the <NORP>Italian</NORP> shore; he respectfully addressed the new Justinian; Peace with the Normans, A.

 Last war of the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> and Normans, A.

 The <NORP>Latin</NORP> historians (124) expatiate on the rapid progress of the <CARDINAL>four</CARDINAL> counts who invaded <GPE>Romania</GPE> with a fleet and army, and reduced many castles and cities to the obedience of the king of Sicily.
 The <NORP>Greeks</NORP> (125) accuse and magnify the wanton and sacrilegious cruelties that were perpetrated in the sack of Thessalonica, the <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> city of the empire.
 The former deplore the fate of those invincible but unsuspecting warriors who were destroyed by the arts of a vanquished foe.
 The latter applaud, in songs of triumph, the repeated victories of their countrymen on the Sea of Marmora or Propontis, on the banks of the Strymon, and under the walls of Durazzo.
 A revolution which punished the crimes of Andronicus, had united against the <PERSON>Franks</PERSON> the zeal and courage of the successful insurgents: <CARDINAL>ten</CARDINAL> thousand were slain in battle, and Isaac Angelus, the new emperor, might indulge his vanity or vengeance in the treatment of <CARDINAL>four</CARDINAL> thousand captives.

 From the <NORP>Arabian</NORP> conquest, <GPE>Sicily</GPE> had imbibed a deep tincture of <NORP>Oriental</NORP> manners; the despotism, the pomp, and even the harem, of a sultan; and a <NORP>Christian</NORP> people was oppressed and insulted by the ascendant of the eunuchs, who openly professed, or secretly cherished, the religion of Mahomet.
 An eloquent historian of the times (126) has delineated the misfortunes of his country: (127) the ambition and fall of the ungrateful Majo; the revolt and punishment of his assassins; the imprisonment and deliverance of the king himself; the private feuds that arose from the public confusion; and the various forms of calamity and discord which afflicted Palermo, the island, and the continent, during the reign of <PERSON>William</PERSON> the First, and the minority of his son.

 Against the unanimous wish of a free people, this inheritance could only be acquired by arms; and I am pleased to transcribe the style and sense of the historian Falcandus, who writes at the moment, and on the spot, with the feelings of a patriot, and the prophetic eye of a statesman.
 Lamentation of the historian Falcandus.
 "Constantia, the daughter of Sicily, nursed from her cradle in the pleasures and plenty, and educated in the arts and manners, of this fortunate isle, departed long since to enrich the <NORP>Barbarians</NORP> with our treasures, and now returns, with her savage allies, to contaminate the beauties of her venerable parent.
 Already I behold the swarms of angry Barbarians: our opulent cities, the places flourishing in a long peace, are shaken with fear, desolated by slaughter, consumed by rapine, and polluted by intemperance and lust.
 I see the massacre or captivity of our citizens, the rapes of our virgins and matrons.
 (129) In this extremity (he interrogates a friend) how must the <NORP>Sicilians</NORP> act? By the unanimous election of a king of valour and experience, <GPE>Sicily</GPE> and <GPE>Calabria</GPE> might yet be preserved; (130) for in the levity of the Apulians, ever eager for new revolutions, I can repose neither confidence nor hope.
 (131) Should <GPE>Calabria</GPE> be lost, the lofty towers, the numerous youth, and the naval strength, of Messina, (132) might guard the passage against a foreign invader.
 If the savage <NORP>Germans</NORP> coalesce with the pirates of Messina; if they destroy with fire the fruitful region, so often wasted by the fires of Mount Aetna, (133) what resource will be left for the interior parts of the island, these noble cities which should never be violated by the hostile footsteps of a Barbarian? (134) <PERSON>Catana</PERSON> has again been overwhelmed by an earthquake: the ancient virtue of <GPE>Syracuse</GPE> expires in poverty and solitude; (135) but <GPE>Palermo</GPE> is still crowned with a diadem, and her triple walls enclose the active multitudes of <NORP>Christians</NORP> and Saracens.
 If the <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> nations, under <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> king, can unite for their common safety, they may rush on the <NORP>Barbarians</NORP> with invincible arms.
 But if the Saracens, fatigued by a repetition of injuries, should now retire and rebel; if they should occupy the castles of the mountains and sea-coast, the unfortunate Christians, exposed to a double attack, and placed as it were between the hammer and the anvil, must resign themselves to hopeless and inevitable servitude.
" (136) We must not forget, that a priest here prefers his country to his religion; and that the Moslems, whose alliance he seeks, were still numerous and powerful in the state of Sicily.
 Conquest of the kingdom of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> by the emperor <PERSON>Henry</PERSON> VI.

 The hopes, or at least the wishes, of <PERSON>Falcandus</PERSON> were at <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> gratified by the free and unanimous election of Tancred, the grandson of the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> king, whose birth was illegitimate, but whose civil and military virtues shone without a blemish.

 But the subtle policy, for which the <FAC>Vatican</FAC> has so often been praised or arraigned, was on this occasion blind and inactive; and if it were true that <PERSON>Celestine</PERSON> the <ORDINAL>Third</ORDINAL> had kicked away the <NORP>Imperial</NORP> crown from the head of the prostrate Henry, (137) such an act of impotent pride could serve only to cancel an obligation and provoke an enemy.

 The last hope of <PERSON>Falcandus</PERSON> was defeated by the discord of the <NORP>Christians</NORP> and Mahometans: they fought in the capital; several <CARDINAL>thousands</CARDINAL> of the latter were slain; but their surviving brethren fortified the mountains, and disturbed above <CARDINAL>thirty</CARDINAL> <DATE>years</DATE> the peace of the island.
 By the policy of <PERSON>Frederic</PERSON> the Second, sixty thousand <NORP>Saracens</NORP> were transplanted to <GPE>Nocera</GPE> in Apulia.
 In their wars against the <NORP>Roman</NORP> church, the emperor and his son <PERSON>Mainfroy</PERSON> were strengthened and disgraced by the service of the enemies of Christ; and this national colony maintained their religion and manners in the heart of Italy, till they were extirpated, at the end of the thirteenth century, by the zeal and revenge of the house of Anjou.
 (139) All the calamities which the prophetic orator had deplored were surpassed by the cruelty and avarice of the <NORP>German</NORP> conqueror.
 He violated the royal sepulchres and explored the secret treasures of the palace, Palermo, and the whole kingdom: the pearls and jewels, however precious, might be easily removed; but <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> hundred and sixty horses were laden with the gold and silver of Sicily.
 (140) The young king, his mother and sisters, and the nobles of both sexes, were separately confined in the fortresses of the Alps; and, on the slightest rumour of rebellion, the captives were deprived of life, of their eyes, or of the hope of posterity.
 <PERSON>Constantia</PERSON> herself was touched with sympathy for the miseries of her country; and the heiress of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> line might struggle to check her despotic husband, and to save the patrimony of her new-born son, of an emperor so famous in the next age under the name of <PERSON>Frederic</PERSON> the Second.
 Final extinction of the Normans, A.

 Ten <DATE>years</DATE> after this revolution, the <NORP>French</NORP> monarchs annexed to their crown the duchy of Normandy: the sceptre of her ancient dukes had been transmitted, by a granddaughter of <PERSON>William</PERSON> the Conqueror, to the house of Plantagenet; and the adventurous Normans, who had raised so many trophies in France, England, and Ireland, in Apulia, Sicily, and the East, were lost, either in victory or servitude, among the vanquished nations.

 His defeat and captivity, June 18.
 On the left, and in the centre, <PERSON>Richard</PERSON> count of Aversa, and <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> the famous Guiscard, attacked, broke, routed, and pursued the <NORP>Italian</NORP> multitudes, who fought without discipline, and fled without shame.
 A harder trial was reserved for the valour of Count Humphrey, who led the cavalry of the right wing.
 The <NORP>Germans</NORP> (34) have been described as unskillful in the management of the horse and the lance, but on foot they formed a strong and impenetrable phalanx; and neither man, nor steed, nor armour, could resist the weight of their long and two-handed swords.
 After a severe conflict, they were encompassed by the squadrons returning from the pursuit; and died in the ranks with the esteem of their foes, and the satisfaction of revenge.
 The gates of <PERSON>Civitella</PERSON> were shut against the flying pope, and he was overtaken by the pious conquerors, who kissed his feet, to implore his blessing and the absolution of their sinful victory.
 The soldiers beheld in their enemy and captive the vicar of Christ; and, though we may suppose the policy of the chiefs, it is probable that they were infected by the popular superstition.
 In the calm of retirement, the well-meaning pope deplored the effusion of <NORP>Christian</NORP> blood, which must be imputed to his account: he felt, that he had been the author of sin and scandal; and as his undertaking had failed, the indecency of his military character was universally condemned.
 (35) With these dispositions, he listened to the offers of a beneficial treaty; deserted an alliance which he had preached as the cause of God; and ratified the past and future conquests of the Normans.
 Origin of the papal investitures to the Normans.
 By whatever hands they had been usurped, the provinces of <GPE>Apulia</GPE> and <GPE>Calabria</GPE> were a part of the donation of <PERSON>Constantine</PERSON> and the patrimony of St.

 They promised to support each other with spiritual and temporal arms; a tribute or quitrent of <CARDINAL>twelve</CARDINAL> pence was afterwards stipulated for every ploughland; and since this memorable transaction, the kingdom of <GPE>Naples</GPE> has remained above <CARDINAL>seven</CARDINAL> hundred <DATE>years</DATE> a fief of the Holy See.
 (36) Birth and character of <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> Guiscard, A.
D.

 The pedigree of <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> of <PERSON>Guiscard</PERSON> (37) is variously deduced from the peasants and the dukes of Normandy: from the peasants, by the pride and ignorance of a <NORP>Grecian</NORP> princess; (38) from the dukes, by the ignorance and flattery of the <NORP>Italian</NORP> subjects.
 (39) His genuine descent may be ascribed to the <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> or middle order of private nobility.
 (40) He sprang from a race of valvassors or bannerets, of the diocese of Coutances, in the Lower Normandy: the castle of <GPE>Hauteville</GPE> was their honourable seat: his father <PERSON>Tancred</PERSON> was conspicuous in the court and army of the duke; and his military service was furnished by <CARDINAL>ten</CARDINAL> soldiers or knights.
 <CARDINAL>Two</CARDINAL> marriages, of a rank not unworthy of his own, made him the father of <CARDINAL>twelve</CARDINAL> sons, who were educated at home by the impartial tenderness of his <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> wife.
 But a narrow patrimony was insufficient for this numerous and daring progeny; they saw around the neighbourhood the mischiefs of poverty and discord, and resolved to seek in foreign wars a more glorious inheritance.
 <CARDINAL>Two</CARDINAL> only remained to perpetuate the race, and cherish their father's age: their <CARDINAL>ten</CARDINAL> brothers, as they successfully attained the vigour of manhood, departed from the castle, passed the Alps, and joined the <NORP>Apulian</NORP> camp of the Normans.
 The elder were prompted by native spirit; their success encouraged their younger brethren, and the <CARDINAL>three</CARDINAL> <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> in seniority, William, Drogo, and Humphrey, deserved to be the chiefs of their nation and the founders of the new republic.
 <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> was the eldest of the <CARDINAL>seven</CARDINAL> sons of the <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> marriage; and even the reluctant praise of his foes has endowed him with the heroic qualities of a soldier and a statesman.
 His lofty stature surpassed the tallest of his army: his limbs were cast in the true proportion of strength and gracefulness; and to the decline of life, he maintained the patient vigour of health and the commanding dignity of his form.
 His complexion was ruddy, his shoulders were broad, his hair and beard were long and of a flaxen colour, his eyes sparkled with fire, and his voice, like that of Achilles, could impress obedience and terror amidst the tumult of battle.
 In the ruder ages of chivalry, such qualifications are not below the notice of the poet or historians: they may observe that Robert, at once, and with equal dexterity, could wield in the right hand his sword, his lance in the left; that in the battle of <PERSON>Civitella</PERSON> he was thrice unhorsed; and that in the close of that memorable day he was adjudged to have borne away the prize of valour from the warriors of the <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> armies.
 (41) His boundless ambition was founded on the consciousness of superior worth: in the pursuit of greatness, he was never arrested by the scruples of justice, and seldom moved by the feelings of humanity: though not insensible of fame, the choice of open or clandestine means was determined only by his present advantage.
 The surname of <PERSON>Guiscard</PERSON> (42) was applied to this master of political wisdom, which is too often confounded with the practice of dissimulation and deceit; and <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> is praised by the <NORP>Apulian</NORP> poet for excelling the cunning of <PERSON>Ulysses</PERSON> and the eloquence of Cicero.
 Yet these arts were disguised by an appearance of military frankness: in his highest fortune, he was accessible and courteous to his fellow-soldiers; and while he indulged the prejudices of his new subjects, he affected in his dress and manners to maintain the ancient fashion of his country.
 He grasped with a rapacious, that he might distribute with a liberal, hand: his primitive indigence had taught the habits of frugality; the gain of a merchant was not below his attention; and his prisoners were tortured with slow and unfeeling cruelty, to force a discovery of their secret treasure.
 According to the Greeks, he departed from <GPE>Normandy</GPE> with only <CARDINAL>five</CARDINAL> followers on horseback and <CARDINAL>thirty</CARDINAL> on foot; yet even this allowance appears too bountiful: the <ORDINAL>sixth</ORDINAL> son of <PERSON>Tancred</PERSON> of <GPE>Hauteville</GPE> passed the <LOC>Alps</LOC> as a pilgrim; and his <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> military band was levied among the adventurers of Italy.
 His brothers and countrymen had divided the fertile lands of Apulia; but they guarded their shares with the jealousy of avarice; the aspiring youth was driven forwards to the mountains of Calabria, and in his <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> exploits against the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> and the natives, it is not easy to discriminate the hero from the robber.
 To surprise a castle or a convent, to ensnare a wealthy citizen, to plunder the adjacent villages for necessary food, were the obscure labours which formed and exercised the powers of his mind and body.
 The volunteers of <GPE>Normandy</GPE> adhered to his standard; and, under his command, the peasants of <GPE>Calabria</GPE> assumed the name and character of Normans.
 His ambition and success, A.
D.
 1054-1080.
 As the genius of <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> expanded with his fortune, he awakened the jealousy of his elder brother, by whom, in a transient quarrel, his life was threatened and his liberty restrained.
 After the death of Humphrey, the tender age of his sons excluded them from the command; they were reduced to a private estate, by the ambition of their guardian and uncle; and <PERSON>Guiscard</PERSON> was exalted on a buckler, and saluted count of <GPE>Apulia</GPE> and general of the republic.
 With an increase of authority and of force, he resumed the conquest of Calabria, and soon aspired to a rank that should raise him forever above the heads of his equals.

 In the hour of triumph, he assembled his troops, and solicited the <NORP>Normans</NORP> to confirm by their suffrage the judgment of the vicar of Christ: Duke of Apulia, A.

 the soldiers hailed with joyful acclamations their valiant duke; and the counts, his former equals, pronounced the oath of fidelity with hollow smiles and secret indignation.
 After this inauguration, <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> styled himself, "By the grace of God and St.

 Such tardy progress, in a narrow space, may seem unworthy of the abilities of the chief and the spirit of the nation; but the <NORP>Normans</NORP> were few in number; their resources were scanty; their service was voluntary and precarious.
 The bravest designs of the duke were sometimes opposed by the free voice of his parliament of barons: the <CARDINAL>twelve</CARDINAL> counts of popular election conspired against his authority; and against their perfidious uncle, the sons of <PERSON>Humphrey</PERSON> demanded justice and revenge.
 By his policy and vigour, <PERSON>Guiscard</PERSON> discovered their plots, suppressed their rebellions, and punished the guilty with death or exile: but in these domestic feuds, his years, and the national strength, were unprofitably consumed.
 After the defeat of his foreign enemies, the Greeks, Lombards, and Saracens, their broken forces retreated to the strong and populous cities of the sea-coast.
 They excelled in the arts of fortification and defence; the <NORP>Normans</NORP> were accustomed to serve on horseback in the field, and their rude attempts could only succeed by the efforts of persevering courage.
 The resistance of <GPE>Salerno</GPE> was maintained above eight months; the siege or blockade of <PERSON>Bari</PERSON> lasted near <CARDINAL>four</CARDINAL> years.
 In these actions the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> duke was the foremost in every danger; in every fatigue the last and most patient.
 As he pressed the citadel of Salerno, a huge stone from the rampart shattered <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> of his military engines; and by a splinter he was wounded in the breast.
 Before the gates of Bari, he lodged in a miserable hut or barrack, composed of dry branches, and thatched with straw; a perilous station, on all sides open to the inclemency of the <DATE>winter</DATE> and the spears of the enemy.
 (45) His <NORP>Italian</NORP> conquests.
 The <NORP>Italian</NORP> conquests of <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> correspond with the limits of the present kingdom of Naples; and the countries united by his arms have not been dissevered by the revolutions of <CARDINAL>seven</CARDINAL> hundred years.
 (46) The monarchy has been composed of the <NORP>Greek</NORP> provinces of <GPE>Calabria</GPE> and Apulia, of the <GPE>Lombard</GPE> principality of Salerno, the republic of Amalphi, and the inland dependencies of the large and ancient duchy of Beneventum.
 <CARDINAL>Three</CARDINAL> districts only were exempted from the common law of subjection; the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> forever, the <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> last till the middle of the succeeding century.
 The city and immediate territory of <PERSON>Benevento</PERSON> had been transferred, by gift or exchange, from the <NORP>German</NORP> emperor to the <NORP>Roman</NORP> pontiff; and although this holy land was sometimes invaded, the name of St.
 Peter was finally more potent than the sword of the Normans.
 Their <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> colony of <PERSON>Aversa</PERSON> subdued and held the state of Capua; and her princes were reduced to beg their bread before the palace of their fathers.
 The dukes of Naples, the present metropolis, maintained the popular freedom, under the shadow of the <NORP>Byzantine</NORP> empire.
 Among the new acquisitions of Guiscard, the science of Salerno, (47) and the trade of Amalphi, (48) may detain for a moment the curiosity of the reader.
 School of Salerno.
 I.
 Of the learned faculties, jurisprudence implies the previous establishment of laws and property; and theology may perhaps be superseded by the full light of religion and reason.
 But the savage and the sage must alike implore the assistance of physic; and, if our diseases are inflamed by luxury, the mischiefs of blows and wounds would be more frequent in the ruder ages of society.
 The treasures of <NORP>Grecian</NORP> medicine had been communicated to the <NORP>Arabian</NORP> colonies of Africa, Spain, and Sicily; and in the intercourse of peace and war, a spark of knowledge had been kindled and cherished at Salerno, an illustrious city, in which the men were honest and the women beautiful.
 (49) A school, the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> that arose in the darkness of Europe, was consecrated to the healing art: the conscience of monks and bishops was reconciled to that salutary and lucrative profession; and a crowd of patients, of the most eminent rank, and most distant climates, invited or visited the physicians of Salerno.
 They were protected by the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> conquerors; and Guiscard, though bred in arms, could discern the merit and value of a philosopher.
 After a pilgrimage of thirty-nine years, Constantine, an <NORP>African</NORP> Christian, returned from Bagdad, a master of the language and learning of the Arabians; and <GPE>Salerno</GPE> was enriched by the practice, the lessons, and the writings of the pupil of Avicenna.
 The school of medicine has long slept in the name of a university; but her precepts are abridged in a string of aphorisms, bound together in the <NORP>Leonine</NORP> verses, or <NORP>Latin</NORP> rhymes, of the <ORDINAL>twelfth</ORDINAL> century.
 (50) Trade of Amalphi.
 II.
 Seven miles to the west of Salerno, and <CARDINAL>thirty</CARDINAL> to the south of Naples, the obscure town of <ORG>Amalphi</ORG> displayed the power and rewards of industry.
 The land, however fertile, was of narrow extent; but the sea was accessible and open: the inhabitants <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> assumed the office of supplying the western world with the manufactures and productions of the East; and this useful traffic was the source of their opulence and freedom.
 The government was popular, under the administration of a duke and the supremacy of the <NORP>Greek</NORP> emperor.
 Fifty thousand citizens were numbered in the walls of Amalphi; nor was any city more abundantly provided with gold, silver, and the objects of precious luxury.
 The mariners who swarmed in her port, excelled in the theory and practice of navigation and astronomy: and the discovery of the compass, which has opened the globe, is owing to their ingenuity or good fortune.
 Their trade was extended to the coasts, or at least to the commodities, of Africa, Arabia, and India: and their settlements in Constantinople, Antioch, Jerusalem, and Alexandria, acquired the privileges of independent colonies.
 (51) After <CARDINAL>three</CARDINAL> hundred <DATE>years</DATE> of prosperity, <ORG>Amalphi</ORG> was oppressed by the arms of the Normans, and sacked by the jealousy of Pisa; but the poverty of <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> thousand fisherman is yet dignified by the remains of an arsenal, a cathedral, and the palaces of royal merchants.
 Conquest of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> by count Roger, A.
D.
 1060-1090.
 Roger, the <ORDINAL>twelfth</ORDINAL> and last of the sons of Tancred, had been long detained in <GPE>Normandy</GPE> by his own and his father' age.
 He accepted the welcome summons; hastened to the <NORP>Apulian</NORP> camp; and deserved at <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> the esteem, and afterwards the envy, of his elder brother.
 Their valour and ambition were equal; but the youth, the beauty, the elegant manners, of <PERSON>Roger</PERSON> engaged the disinterested love of the soldiers and people.
 So scanty was his allowance for himself and <CARDINAL>forty</CARDINAL> followers, that he descended from conquest to robbery, and from robbery to domestic theft; and so loose were the notions of property, that, by his own historian, at his special command, he is accused of stealing horses from a stable at Melphi.
 (52) His spirit emerged from poverty and disgrace: from these base practices he rose to the merit and glory of a holy war; and the invasion of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> was seconded by the zeal and policy of his brother Guiscard.
 After the retreat of the Greeks, the idolaters, a most audacious reproach of the Catholics, had retrieved their losses and possessions; but the deliverance of the island, so vainly undertaken by the forces of the <NORP>Eastern</NORP> empire, was achieved by a small and private band of adventurers.
 (53) In the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> attempt, <PERSON>Roger</PERSON> braved, in an open boat, the real and fabulous dangers of <PRODUCT>Scylla</PRODUCT> and Charybdis; landed with only sixty soldiers on a hostile shore; drove the <NORP>Saracens</NORP> to the gates of <GPE>Messina</GPE> and safely returned with the spoils of the adjacent country.
 In the fortress of Trani, his active and patient courage were equally conspicuous.
 In his old age he related with pleasure, that, by the distress of the siege, himself, and the countess his wife, had been reduced to a single cloak or mantle, which they wore alternately; that in a sally his horse had been slain, and he was dragged away by the Saracens; but that he owed his rescue to his good sword, and had retreated with his saddle on his back, lest the meanest trophy might be left in the hands of the miscreants.
 In the siege of Trani, <CARDINAL>three</CARDINAL> hundred <NORP>Normans</NORP> withstood and repulsed the forces of the island.
 In the field of Ceramio, <CARDINAL>fifty</CARDINAL> thousand horse and foot were overthrown by <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> hundred and <CARDINAL>thirty-six</CARDINAL> <NORP>Christian</NORP> soldiers, without reckoning St.
 George, who fought on horseback in the foremost ranks.
 The captive banners, with <CARDINAL>four</CARDINAL> camels, were reserved for the successor of St.

 These insufficient numbers of the <NORP>Normans</NORP> most probably denote their knights, the soldiers of honorable and equestrian rank, each of whom was attended by <CARDINAL>five</CARDINAL> or <CARDINAL>six</CARDINAL> followers in the field; (54) yet, with the aid of this interpretation, and after every fair allowance on the side of valour, arms, and reputation, the discomfiture of so many myriads will reduce the prudent reader to the alternative of a miracle or a fable.
 The <NORP>Arabs</NORP> of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> derived a frequent and powerful succour from their countrymen of Africa: in the siege of Palermo, the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> cavalry was assisted by the galleys of Pisa; and, in the hour of action, the envy of the <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> brothers was sublimed to a generous and invincible emulation.
 After a war of <CARDINAL>thirty</CARDINAL> years, (55) Roger, with the title of great count, obtained the sovereignty of the largest and most fruitful island of the Mediterranean; and his administration displays a liberal and enlightened mind, above the limits of his age and education.
 The <NORP>Moslems</NORP> were maintained in the free enjoyment of their religion and property: (56) a philosopher and physician of Mazara, of the race of Mahomet, harangued the conqueror, and was invited to court; his geography of the <CARDINAL>seven</CARDINAL> climates was translated into Latin; and Roger, after a diligent perusal, preferred the work of the <NORP>Arabian</NORP> to the writings of the <NORP>Grecian</NORP> Ptolemy.
 (57) A remnant of <NORP>Christian</NORP> natives had promoted the success of the Normans: they were rewarded by the triumph of the cross.
 The island was restored to the jurisdiction of the <NORP>Roman</NORP> pontiff; new bishops were planted in the principal cities; and the clergy was satisfied by a liberal endowment of churches and monasteries.
 Yet the <NORP>Catholic</NORP> hero asserted the rights of the civil magistrate.
 Instead of resigning the investiture of benefices, he dexterously applied to his own profit the papal claims: the supremacy of the crown was secured and enlarged, by the singular bull, which declares the princes of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> hereditary and perpetual legates of the Holy See.
 (58) <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> invades the <NORP>Eastern</NORP> empire, A.
D.

 To <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> Guiscard, the conquest of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> was more glorious than beneficial: the possession of <GPE>Apulia</GPE> and <GPE>Calabria</GPE> was inadequate to his ambition; and he resolved to embrace or create the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> occasion of invading, perhaps of subduing, the <NORP>Roman</NORP> empire of the East.

 The fraud had been contrived by the subtle Guiscard; and he trusted, that after this pretender had given a decent colour to his arms, he would sink, at the nod of the conqueror, into his primitive obscurity.

 Thirteen hundred knights (63) of <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> race or discipline, formed the sinews of the army, which might be swelled to <CARDINAL>thirty</CARDINAL> thousand (64) followers of every denomination.

 Siege of Durazzo, A.
D.
 1081, June 17.
 At the mouth of the <LOC>Adriatic</LOC> Gulf, the shores of <GPE>Italy</GPE> and <LOC>Epirus</LOC> incline towards each other.
 The space between <PRODUCT>Brundusium</PRODUCT> and Durazzo, the <NORP>Roman</NORP> passage, is no more than <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> hundred miles; (65) at the last station of Otranto, it is contracted to fifty; (66) and this narrow distance had suggested to <PERSON>Pyrrhus</PERSON> and <PERSON>Pompey</PERSON> the sublime or extravagant idea of a bridge.
 Before the general embarkation, the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> duke despatched <PERSON>Bohemond</PERSON> with <CARDINAL>fifteen</CARDINAL> galleys to seize or threaten the Isle of Corfu, to survey the opposite coast, and to secure a harbour in the neighbourhood of <GPE>Vallona</GPE> for the landing of the troops.
 They passed and landed without perceiving an enemy; and this successful experiment displayed the neglect and decay of the naval power of the Greeks.
 The islands of <LOC>Epirus</LOC> and the maritime towns were subdued by the arms or the name of Robert, who led his fleet and army from <PERSON>Corfu</PERSON> (I use the modern appellation) to the siege of Durazzo.
 That city, the western key of the empire, was guarded by ancient renown, and recent fortifications, by <PERSON>George</PERSON> Palaeologus, a patrician, victorious in the <NORP>Oriental</NORP> wars, and a numerous garrison of <NORP>Albanians</NORP> and Macedonians, who, in every age, have maintained the character of soldiers.
 In the prosecution of his enterprise, the courage of <PERSON>Guiscard</PERSON> was assailed by every form of danger and mischance.
 In the most propitious season of the year, as his fleet passed along the coast, a storm of wind and snow unexpectedly arose: the <LOC>Adriatic</LOC> was swelled by the raging blast of the south, and a new shipwreck confirmed the old infamy of the <NORP>Acroceraunian</NORP> rocks.
 (67) The sails, the masts, and the oars, were shattered or torn away; the sea and shore were covered with the fragments of vessels, with arms and dead bodies; and the greatest part of the provisions were either drowned or damaged.
 The ducal galley was laboriously rescued from the waves, and <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> halted <CARDINAL>seven</CARDINAL> days on the adjacent cape, to collect the relics of his loss, and revive the drooping spirits of his soldiers.
 The <NORP>Normans</NORP> were no longer the bold and experienced mariners who had explored the ocean from <LOC>Greenland</LOC> to Mount Atlas, and who smiled at the petty dangers of the Mediterranean.
 They had wept during the tempest; they were alarmed by the hostile approach of the Venetians, who had been solicited by the prayers and promises of the <NORP>Byzantine</NORP> court.
 The <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> day's action was not disadvantageous to Bohemond, a beardless youth, (68) who led the naval powers of his father.
 All night the galleys of the republic lay on their anchors in the form of a crescent; and the victory of the <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> day was decided by the dexterity of their evolutions, the station of their archers, the weight of their javelins, and the borrowed aid of the <NORP>Greek</NORP> fire.
 The <NORP>Apulian</NORP> and <NORP>Ragusian</NORP> vessels fled to the shore, several were cut from their cables, and dragged away by the conqueror; and a sally from the town carried slaughter and dismay to the tents of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> duke.
 A seasonable relief was poured into Durazzo, and as soon as the besiegers had lost the command of the sea, the islands and maritime towns withdrew from the camp the supply of tribute and provision.
 That camp was soon afflicted with a pestilential disease; <CARDINAL>five</CARDINAL> hundred knights perished by an inglorious death; and the list of burials (if all could obtain a decent burial) amounted to <CARDINAL>ten</CARDINAL> thousand persons.
 Under these calamities, the mind of <PERSON>Guiscard</PERSON> alone was firm and invincible; and while he collected new forces from <GPE>Apulia</GPE> and Sicily, he battered, or scaled, or sapped, the walls of Durazzo.
 But his industry and valour were encountered by equal valour and more perfect industry.
 A movable turret, of a size and capacity to contain <CARDINAL>five</CARDINAL> hundred soldiers, had been rolled forwards to the foot of the rampart: but the descent of the door or drawbridge was checked by an enormous beam, and the wooden structure was constantly consumed by artificial flames.
 The army and the march of the emperor Alexius, April-September.
 While the <NORP>Roman</NORP> empire was attacked by the <NORP>Turks</NORP> in the East, east, and the <NORP>Normans</NORP> in the West, the aged successor of <PERSON>Michael</PERSON> surrendered the sceptre to the hands of Alexius, an illustrious captain, and the founder of the <NORP>Comnenian</NORP> dynasty.
 The princess Anne, his daughter and historian, observes, in her affected style, that even <PERSON>Hercules</PERSON> was unequal to a double combat; and, on this principle, she approves a hasty peace with the Turks, which allowed her father to undertake in person the relief of Durazzo.
 On his accession, <PERSON>Alexius</PERSON> found the camp without soldiers, and the treasury without money; yet such were the vigour and activity of his measures, that in <CARDINAL>six</CARDINAL> months he assembled an army of <CARDINAL>seventy</CARDINAL> thousand men, (69) and performed a march of <CARDINAL>five</CARDINAL> hundred miles.
 His troops were levied in <LOC>Europe</LOC> and Asia, from <LOC>Peloponnesus</LOC> to the Black Sea; his majesty was displayed in the silver arms and rich trappings of the companies of Horse-guards; and the emperor was attended by a train of nobles and princes, some of whom, in rapid succession, had been clothed with the purple, and were indulged by the lenity of the times in a life of affluence and dignity.
 Their youthful ardour might animate the multitude; but their love of pleasure and contempt of subordination were pregnant with disorder and mischief; and their importunate clamours for speedy and decisive action disconcerted the prudence of Alexius, who might have surrounded and starved the besieging army.
 The enumeration of provinces recalls a sad comparison of the past and present limits of the <NORP>Roman</NORP> world: the raw levies were drawn together in haste and terror; and the garrisons of Anatolia, or <LOC>Asia</LOC> Minor, had been purchased by the evacuation of the cities which were immediately occupied by the Turks.
 The strength of the <NORP>Greek</NORP> army consisted in the Varangians, the <NORP>Scandinavian</NORP> guards, whose numbers were recently augmented by a colony of exiles and volunteers from the British Island of Thule.
 Under the yoke of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> conqueror, the <NORP>Danes</NORP> and <LANGUAGE>English</LANGUAGE> were oppressed and united; a band of adventurous youths resolved to desert a land of slavery; the sea was open to their escape; and, in their long pilgrimage, they visited every coast that afforded any hope of liberty and revenge.
 They were entertained in the service of the <NORP>Greek</NORP> emperor; and their <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> station was in a new city on the <NORP>Asiatic</NORP> shore: but <PERSON>Alexius</PERSON> soon recalled them to the defence of his person and palace; and bequeathed to his successors the inheritance of their faith and valour.
 (70) The name of a <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> invader revived the memory of their wrongs: they marched with alacrity against the national foe, and panted to regain in <LOC>Epirus</LOC> the glory which they had lost in the battle of Hastings.
 The <NORP>Varangians</NORP> were supported by some companies of <PERSON>Franks</PERSON> or Latins; and the rebels, who had fled to <GPE>Constantinople</GPE> from the tyranny of Guiscard, were eager to signalize their zeal and gratify their revenge.

 (71) The treaty with the sultan had procured a supply of some thousand Turks; and the arrows of the <NORP>Scythian</NORP> horse were opposed to the lances of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> cavalry.
 On the report and distant prospect of these formidable numbers, <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> assembled a council of his principal officers.
 "You behold," said he, "your danger: it is urgent and inevitable.
 The hills are covered with arms and standards; and the emperor of the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> is accustomed to wars and triumphs.
 Obedience and union are our only safety; and I am ready to yield the command to a more worthy leader.
" The vote and acclamation even of his secret enemies, assured him, in that perilous moment, of their esteem and confidence; and the duke thus continued: "Let us trust in the rewards of victory, and deprive cowardice of the means of escape.
 Let us burn our vessels and our baggage, and give battle on this spot, as if it were the place of our nativity and our burial.
" The resolution was unanimously approved; and, without confining himself to his lines, <PERSON>Guiscard</PERSON> awaited in battle-array the nearer approach of the enemy.
 His rear was covered by a small river; his right wing extended to the sea; his left to the hills: nor was he conscious, perhaps, that on the same ground <PERSON>Caesar</PERSON> and <PERSON>Pompey</PERSON> had formerly disputed the empire of the world.
 (72) Battle of Durazzo, A.
D.
 1081, <DATE>October</DATE> 18.
 Against the advice of his wisest captains, <PERSON>Alexius</PERSON> resolved to risk the event of a general action, and exhorted the garrison of <ORG>Durazzo</ORG> to assist their own deliverance by a well-timed sally from the town.

 (75) <PERSON>Alexius</PERSON> was not deficient in the duties of a soldier or a general; but he no sooner beheld the slaughter of the Varangians, and the flight of the Turks, than he despised his subjects, and despaired of his fortune.

 <ORG>Durazzo</ORG> taken, A.
D.
 1082, February 8.
 It is more than probable that <PERSON>Guiscard</PERSON> was not afflicted by the loss of a costly pageant, which had merited only the contempt and derision of the Greeks.

 (96) Reign and ambition of Roger, great count of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> , A.

 His conquests in Africa, A.
D.

 As a penance for his impious war against the successor of St.

 His invasion of Greece, A.
D.

 (111) The emperor <PERSON>Manuel</PERSON> repulses the Normans, A.

 It was the right and duty, it might be the interest and glory, of <PERSON>Manuel</PERSON> to restore the ancient majesty of the empire, to recover the provinces of <GPE>Italy</GPE> and Sicily, and to chastise this pretended king, the grandson of a <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> vassal.

 The former deplore the fate of those invincible but unsuspecting warriors who were destroyed by the arts of a vanquished foe.
 The latter applaud, in songs of triumph, the repeated victories of their countrymen on the Sea of Marmora or Propontis, on the banks of the Strymon, and under the walls of Durazzo.
 A revolution which punished the crimes of Andronicus, had united against the <PERSON>Franks</PERSON> the zeal and courage of the successful insurgents: <CARDINAL>ten</CARDINAL> thousand were slain in battle, and Isaac Angelus, the new emperor, might indulge his vanity or vengeance in the treatment of <CARDINAL>four</CARDINAL> thousand captives.

 An eloquent historian of the times (126) has delineated the misfortunes of his country: (127) the ambition and fall of the ungrateful Majo; the revolt and punishment of his assassins; the imprisonment and deliverance of the king himself; the private feuds that arose from the public confusion; and the various forms of calamity and discord which afflicted Palermo, the island, and the continent, during the reign of <PERSON>William</PERSON> the First, and the minority of his son.

 Against the unanimous wish of a free people, this inheritance could only be acquired by arms; and I am pleased to transcribe the style and sense of the historian Falcandus, who writes at the moment, and on the spot, with the feelings of a patriot, and the prophetic eye of a statesman.
 Lamentation of the historian Falcandus.
 "Constantia, the daughter of Sicily, nursed from her cradle in the pleasures and plenty, and educated in the arts and manners, of this fortunate isle, departed long since to enrich the <NORP>Barbarians</NORP> with our treasures, and now returns, with her savage allies, to contaminate the beauties of her venerable parent.
 Already I behold the swarms of angry Barbarians: our opulent cities, the places flourishing in a long peace, are shaken with fear, desolated by slaughter, consumed by rapine, and polluted by intemperance and lust.
 I see the massacre or captivity of our citizens, the rapes of our virgins and matrons.
 (129) In this extremity (he interrogates a friend) how must the <NORP>Sicilians</NORP> act? By the unanimous election of a king of valour and experience, <GPE>Sicily</GPE> and <GPE>Calabria</GPE> might yet be preserved; (130) for in the levity of the Apulians, ever eager for new revolutions, I can repose neither confidence nor hope.
 (131) Should <GPE>Calabria</GPE> be lost, the lofty towers, the numerous youth, and the naval strength, of Messina, (132) might guard the passage against a foreign invader.
 If the savage <NORP>Germans</NORP> coalesce with the pirates of Messina; if they destroy with fire the fruitful region, so often wasted by the fires of Mount Aetna, (133) what resource will be left for the interior parts of the island, these noble cities which should never be violated by the hostile footsteps of a Barbarian? (134) <PERSON>Catana</PERSON> has again been overwhelmed by an earthquake: the ancient virtue of <GPE>Syracuse</GPE> expires in poverty and solitude; (135) but <GPE>Palermo</GPE> is still crowned with a diadem, and her triple walls enclose the active multitudes of <NORP>Christians</NORP> and Saracens.
 If the <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> nations, under <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> king, can unite for their common safety, they may rush on the <NORP>Barbarians</NORP> with invincible arms.
 But if the Saracens, fatigued by a repetition of injuries, should now retire and rebel; if they should occupy the castles of the mountains and sea-coast, the unfortunate Christians, exposed to a double attack, and placed as it were between the hammer and the anvil, must resign themselves to hopeless and inevitable servitude.
" (136) We must not forget, that a priest here prefers his country to his religion; and that the Moslems, whose alliance he seeks, were still numerous and powerful in the state of Sicily.
 Conquest of the kingdom of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> by the emperor <PERSON>Henry</PERSON> VI.

 The hopes, or at least the wishes, of <PERSON>Falcandus</PERSON> were at <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> gratified by the free and unanimous election of Tancred, the grandson of the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> king, whose birth was illegitimate, but whose civil and military virtues shone without a blemish.

 The political balance of <GPE>Italy</GPE> was destroyed by his success; and if the pope and the free cities had consulted their obvious and real interest, they would have combined the powers of earth and heaven to prevent the dangerous union of the <NORP>German</NORP> empire with the kingdom of Sicily.
 But the subtle policy, for which the <FAC>Vatican</FAC> has so often been praised or arraigned, was on this occasion blind and inactive; and if it were true that <PERSON>Celestine</PERSON> the <ORDINAL>Third</ORDINAL> had kicked away the <NORP>Imperial</NORP> crown from the head of the prostrate Henry, (137) such an act of impotent pride could serve only to cancel an obligation and provoke an enemy.

 The last hope of <PERSON>Falcandus</PERSON> was defeated by the discord of the <NORP>Christians</NORP> and Mahometans: they fought in the capital; several <CARDINAL>thousands</CARDINAL> of the latter were slain; but their surviving brethren fortified the mountains, and disturbed above <CARDINAL>thirty</CARDINAL> <DATE>years</DATE> the peace of the island.
 By the policy of <PERSON>Frederic</PERSON> the Second, sixty thousand <NORP>Saracens</NORP> were transplanted to <GPE>Nocera</GPE> in Apulia.
 In their wars against the <NORP>Roman</NORP> church, the emperor and his son <PERSON>Mainfroy</PERSON> were strengthened and disgraced by the service of the enemies of Christ; and this national colony maintained their religion and manners in the heart of Italy, till they were extirpated, at the end of the thirteenth century, by the zeal and revenge of the house of Anjou.
 (139) All the calamities which the prophetic orator had deplored were surpassed by the cruelty and avarice of the <NORP>German</NORP> conqueror.
 He violated the royal sepulchres and explored the secret treasures of the palace, Palermo, and the whole kingdom: the pearls and jewels, however precious, might be easily removed; but <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> hundred and sixty horses were laden with the gold and silver of Sicily.
 (140) The young king, his mother and sisters, and the nobles of both sexes, were separately confined in the fortresses of the Alps; and, on the slightest rumour of rebellion, the captives were deprived of life, of their eyes, or of the hope of posterity.
 <PERSON>Constantia</PERSON> herself was touched with sympathy for the miseries of her country; and the heiress of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> line might struggle to check her despotic husband, and to save the patrimony of her new-born son, of an emperor so famous in the next age under the name of <PERSON>Frederic</PERSON> the Second.
 Final extinction of the Normans, A.
D.
 1204.
 Ten <DATE>years</DATE> after this revolution, the <NORP>French</NORP> monarchs annexed to their crown the duchy of Normandy: the sceptre of her ancient dukes had been transmitted, by a granddaughter of <PERSON>William</PERSON> the Conqueror, to the house of Plantagenet; and the adventurous Normans, who had raised so many trophies in France, England, and Ireland, in Apulia, Sicily, and the East, were lost, either in victory or servitude, among the vanquished nations.

 The pedigree of <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> of <PERSON>Guiscard</PERSON> (37) is variously deduced from the peasants and the dukes of Normandy: from the peasants, by the pride and ignorance of a <NORP>Grecian</NORP> princess; (38) from the dukes, by the ignorance and flattery of the <NORP>Italian</NORP> subjects.
 (39) His genuine descent may be ascribed to the <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> or middle order of private nobility.
 (40) He sprang from a race of valvassors or bannerets, of the diocese of Coutances, in the Lower Normandy: the castle of <GPE>Hauteville</GPE> was their honourable seat: his father <PERSON>Tancred</PERSON> was conspicuous in the court and army of the duke; and his military service was furnished by <CARDINAL>ten</CARDINAL> soldiers or knights.
 <CARDINAL>Two</CARDINAL> marriages, of a rank not unworthy of his own, made him the father of <CARDINAL>twelve</CARDINAL> sons, who were educated at home by the impartial tenderness of his <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> wife.
 But a narrow patrimony was insufficient for this numerous and daring progeny; they saw around the neighbourhood the mischiefs of poverty and discord, and resolved to seek in foreign wars a more glorious inheritance.
 <CARDINAL>Two</CARDINAL> only remained to perpetuate the race, and cherish their father's age: their <CARDINAL>ten</CARDINAL> brothers, as they successfully attained the vigour of manhood, departed from the castle, passed the Alps, and joined the <NORP>Apulian</NORP> camp of the Normans.
 The elder were prompted by native spirit; their success encouraged their younger brethren, and the <CARDINAL>three</CARDINAL> <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> in seniority, William, Drogo, and Humphrey, deserved to be the chiefs of their nation and the founders of the new republic.
 <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> was the eldest of the <CARDINAL>seven</CARDINAL> sons of the <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> marriage; and even the reluctant praise of his foes has endowed him with the heroic qualities of a soldier and a statesman.
 His lofty stature surpassed the tallest of his army: his limbs were cast in the true proportion of strength and gracefulness; and to the decline of life, he maintained the patient vigour of health and the commanding dignity of his form.
 His complexion was ruddy, his shoulders were broad, his hair and beard were long and of a flaxen colour, his eyes sparkled with fire, and his voice, like that of Achilles, could impress obedience and terror amidst the tumult of battle.
 In the ruder ages of chivalry, such qualifications are not below the notice of the poet or historians: they may observe that Robert, at once, and with equal dexterity, could wield in the right hand his sword, his lance in the left; that in the battle of <PERSON>Civitella</PERSON> he was thrice unhorsed; and that in the close of that memorable day he was adjudged to have borne away the prize of valour from the warriors of the <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> armies.
 (41) His boundless ambition was founded on the consciousness of superior worth: in the pursuit of greatness, he was never arrested by the scruples of justice, and seldom moved by the feelings of humanity: though not insensible of fame, the choice of open or clandestine means was determined only by his present advantage.
 The surname of <PERSON>Guiscard</PERSON> (42) was applied to this master of political wisdom, which is too often confounded with the practice of dissimulation and deceit; and <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> is praised by the <NORP>Apulian</NORP> poet for excelling the cunning of <PERSON>Ulysses</PERSON> and the eloquence of Cicero.
 Yet these arts were disguised by an appearance of military frankness: in his highest fortune, he was accessible and courteous to his fellow-soldiers; and while he indulged the prejudices of his new subjects, he affected in his dress and manners to maintain the ancient fashion of his country.
 He grasped with a rapacious, that he might distribute with a liberal, hand: his primitive indigence had taught the habits of frugality; the gain of a merchant was not below his attention; and his prisoners were tortured with slow and unfeeling cruelty, to force a discovery of their secret treasure.
 According to the Greeks, he departed from <GPE>Normandy</GPE> with only <CARDINAL>five</CARDINAL> followers on horseback and <CARDINAL>thirty</CARDINAL> on foot; yet even this allowance appears too bountiful: the <ORDINAL>sixth</ORDINAL> son of <PERSON>Tancred</PERSON> of <GPE>Hauteville</GPE> passed the <LOC>Alps</LOC> as a pilgrim; and his <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> military band was levied among the adventurers of Italy.
 His brothers and countrymen had divided the fertile lands of Apulia; but they guarded their shares with the jealousy of avarice; the aspiring youth was driven forwards to the mountains of Calabria, and in his <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> exploits against the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> and the natives, it is not easy to discriminate the hero from the robber.
 To surprise a castle or a convent, to ensnare a wealthy citizen, to plunder the adjacent villages for necessary food, were the obscure labours which formed and exercised the powers of his mind and body.
 The volunteers of <GPE>Normandy</GPE> adhered to his standard; and, under his command, the peasants of <GPE>Calabria</GPE> assumed the name and character of Normans.
 His ambition and success, A.
D.
 1054-1080.
 As the genius of <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> expanded with his fortune, he awakened the jealousy of his elder brother, by whom, in a transient quarrel, his life was threatened and his liberty restrained.
 After the death of Humphrey, the tender age of his sons excluded them from the command; they were reduced to a private estate, by the ambition of their guardian and uncle; and <PERSON>Guiscard</PERSON> was exalted on a buckler, and saluted count of <GPE>Apulia</GPE> and general of the republic.
 With an increase of authority and of force, he resumed the conquest of Calabria, and soon aspired to a rank that should raise him forever above the heads of his equals.
 By some acts of rapine or sacrilege, he had incurred a papal excommunication; but <PERSON>Nicholas</PERSON> the <ORDINAL>Second</ORDINAL> was easily persuaded that the divisions of friends could terminate only in their mutual prejudice; that the <NORP>Normans</NORP> were the faithful champions of the Holy See; and it was safer to trust the alliance of a prince than the caprice of an aristocracy.
 A synod of <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> hundred bishops was convened at Melphi; and the count interrupted an important enterprise to guard the person and execute the decrees of the <NORP>Roman</NORP> pontiff.
 His gratitude and policy conferred on <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> and his posterity the ducal title, (43) with the investiture of Apulia, Calabria, and all the lands, both in <GPE>Italy</GPE> and Sicily, which his sword could rescue from the schismatic <NORP>Greeks</NORP> and the unbelieving Saracens.
 (44) This apostolic sanction might justify his arms; but the obedience of a free and victorious people could not be transferred without their consent; and <PERSON>Guiscard</PERSON> dissembled his elevation till the ensuing campaign had been illustrated by the conquest of <PERSON>Consenza</PERSON> and Reggio.
 In the hour of triumph, he assembled his troops, and solicited the <NORP>Normans</NORP> to confirm by their suffrage the judgment of the vicar of Christ: Duke of Apulia, A.
D.
