 After a gallant resistance, the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> prince was driven from the continent of Italy: a new duke of <GPE>Apulia</GPE> was invested by the pope and the emperor, each of whom held <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> end of the gonfanon, or flagstaff, as a token that they asserted their right, and suspended their quarrel.
 But such jealous friendship was of short and precarious duration: the <NORP>German</NORP> armies soon vanished in disease and desertion: (102) the <NORP>Apulian</NORP> duke, with all his adherents, was exterminated by a conqueror who seldom forgave either the dead or the living; like his predecessor <PERSON>Leo</PERSON> the Ninth, the feeble though haughty pontiff became the captive and friend of the Normans; and their reconciliation was celebrated by the eloquence of Bernard, who now revered the title and virtues of the king of Sicily.
 His conquests in Africa, A.
D.
 1122-1152.
 As a penance for his impious war against the successor of St.
 Peter, that monarch might have promised to display the banner of the cross, and he accomplished with ardour a vow so propitious to his interest and revenge.
 The recent injuries of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> might provoke a just retaliation on the heads of the Saracens: the Normans, whose blood had been mingled with so many subject streams, were encouraged to remember and emulate the naval trophies of their fathers, and in the maturity of their strength they contended with the decline of an <NORP>African</NORP> power.
 When the <NORP>Fatimite</NORP> caliph departed for the conquest of Egypt, he rewarded the real merit and apparent fidelity of his servant <PERSON>Joseph</PERSON> with a gift of his royal mantle, and <CARDINAL>forty</CARDINAL> <NORP>Arabian</NORP> horses, his palace with its sumptuous furniture, and the government of the kingdoms of <GPE>Tunis</GPE> and Algiers.
 The Zeirides, (103) the descendants of Joseph, forgot their allegiance and gratitude to a distant benefactor, grasped and abused the fruits of prosperity; and after running the little course of an <NORP>Oriental</NORP> dynasty, were now fainting in their own weakness.
 On the side of the land, they were pressed by the Almohades, the fanatic princes of Morocco, while the sea-coast was open to the enterprises of the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> and Franks, who, before the close of the eleventh century, had extorted a ransom of <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> hundred thousand pieces of gold.
 By the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> arms of Roger, the island or rock of Malta, which has been since ennobled by a military and religious colony, was inseparably annexed to the crown of Sicily.
 Tripoli, (104) a strong and maritime city, was the next object of his attack; and the slaughter of the males, the captivity of the females, might be justified by the frequent practice of the <NORP>Moslems</NORP> themselves.
 The capital of the <GPE>Zeirides</GPE> was named <LOC>Africa</LOC> from the country, and <PERSON>Mahadia</PERSON> (105) from the <NORP>Arabian</NORP> founder: it is strongly built on a neck of land, but the imperfection of the harbour is not compensated by the fertility of the adjacent plain.
 <PERSON>Mahadia</PERSON> was besieged by <PERSON>George</PERSON> the <NORP>Sicilian</NORP> admiral, with a fleet of <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> hundred and <CARDINAL>fifty</CARDINAL> galleys, amply provided with men and the instruments of mischief: the sovereign had fled, the <NORP>Moorish</NORP> governor refused to capitulate, declined the last and irresistible assault, and secretly escaping with the <NORP>Moslem</NORP> inhabitants abandoned the place and its treasures to the rapacious Franks.
 In successive expeditions, the king of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> or his lieutenants reduced the cities of Tunis, Safax, Capsia, Bona, and a long tract of the sea-coast; (106) the fortresses were garrisoned, the country was tributary, and a boast that it held <LOC>Africa</LOC> in subjection might be inscribed with some flattery on the sword of Roger.
 (107) After his death, that sword was broken; and these transmarine possessions were neglected, evacuated, or lost, under the troubled reign of his successor.
 (108) The triumphs of <PERSON>Scipio</PERSON> and <PERSON>Belisarius</PERSON> have proved, that the <NORP>African</NORP> continent is neither inaccessible nor invincible; yet the great princes and powers of <NORP>Christendom</NORP> have repeatedly failed in their armaments against the Moors, who may still glory in the easy conquest and long servitude of Spain.
 His invasion of Greece, A.
D.
 1146.
 Since the decease of <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> Guiscard, the <NORP>Normans</NORP> had relinquished, above sixty years, their hostile designs against the empire of the East.
 The policy of <PERSON>Roger</PERSON> solicited a public and private union with the <NORP>Greek</NORP> princes, whose alliance would dignify his regal character: he demanded in marriage a daughter of the <NORP>Comnenian</NORP> family, and the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> steps of the treaty seemed to promise a favourable event.
 But the contemptuous treatment of his ambassadors exasperated the vanity of the new monarch; and the insolence of the <NORP>Byzantine</NORP> court was expiated, according to the laws of nations, by the sufferings of a guiltless people.
 (109) With the fleet of <CARDINAL>seventy</CARDINAL> galleys, George, the admiral of Sicily, appeared before Corfu; and both the island and city were delivered into his hands by the disaffected inhabitants, who had yet to learn that a siege is still more calamitous than a tribute.
 In this invasion, of some moment in the annals of commerce, the <NORP>Normans</NORP> spread themselves by sea, and over the provinces of Greece; and the venerable age of Athens, Thebes, and Corinth, was violated by rapine and cruelty.
 Of the wrongs of Athens, no memorial remains.
 The ancient walls, which encompassed, without guarding, the opulence of Thebes, were scaled by the <NORP>Latin</NORP> Christians; but their sole use of the gospel was to sanctify an oath, that the lawful owners had not secreted any relic of their inheritance or industry.
 On the approach of the Normans, the lower town of <GPE>Corinth</GPE> was evacuated; the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> retired to the citadel, which was seated on a lofty eminence, abundantly watered by the classic fountain of Pirene; an impregnable fortress, if the want of courage could be balanced by any advantages of art or nature.
 As soon as the besiegers had surmounted the labor (their sole labor) of climbing the hill, their general, from the commanding eminence, admired his own victory, and testified his gratitude to Heaven, by tearing from the altar the precious image of Theodore, the tutelary saint.
 The silk weavers of both sexes, whom <PERSON>George</PERSON> transported to Sicily, composed the most valuable part of the spoil; and in comparing the skilful industry of the mechanic with the sloth and cowardice of the soldier, he was heard to exclaim that the distaff and loom were the only weapons which the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> were capable of using.
 His admiral delivers <PERSON>LouisVII</PERSON> of France.
 The progress of this naval armament was marked by <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> conspicuous events, the rescue of the king of France, and the insult of the <NORP>Byzantine</NORP> capital.
 In his return by sea from an unfortunate crusade, <PERSON>Louis</PERSON> the <ORDINAL>Seventh</ORDINAL> was intercepted by the Greeks, who basely violated the laws of honour and religion.
 The fortunate encounter of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> fleet delivered the royal captive; and after a free and honorable entertainment in the court of Sicily, <PERSON>Louis</PERSON> continued his journey to <GPE>Rome</GPE> and Paris.
 (110) insults <GPE>Constantinople</GPE> In the absence of the emperor, <GPE>Constantinople</GPE> and the <PERSON>Hellespont</PERSON> were left without defence and without the suspicion of danger.
 The clergy and people (for the soldiers had followed the standard of Manuel) were astonished and dismayed at the hostile appearance of a line of galleys, which boldly cast anchor in the front of the <NORP>Imperial</NORP> city.
 The forces of the <NORP>Sicilian</NORP> admiral were inadequate to the siege or assault of an immense and populous metropolis; but <PERSON>George</PERSON> enjoyed the glory of humbling the <NORP>Greek</NORP> arrogance, and of marking the path of conquest to the navies of the West.
 He landed some soldiers to rifle the fruits of the royal gardens, and pointed with silver, or most probably with fire, the arrows which he discharged against the palace of the Caesars.
 (111) The emperor <PERSON>Manuel</PERSON> repulses the Normans, A.
D.

 This playful outrage of the pirates of Sicily, who had surprised an unguarded moment, <PERSON>Manuel</PERSON> affected to despise, while his martial spirit, and the forces of the empire, were awakened to revenge.
 The <LOC>Archipelago</LOC> and Ionian Sea were covered with his squadrons and those of Venice; but I know not by what favourable allowance of transports, victuallers, and pinnaces, our reason, or even our fancy, can be reconciled to the stupendous account of <CARDINAL>fifteen</CARDINAL> hundred vessels, which is proposed by a <NORP>Byzantine</NORP> historian.
 These operations were directed with prudence and energy: in his homeward voyage <PERSON>George</PERSON> lost <CARDINAL>nineteen</CARDINAL> of his galleys, which were separated and taken: after an obstinate defence, <PERSON>Corfu</PERSON> implored the clemency of her lawful sovereign; nor could a ship, a soldier, of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> prince, be found, unless as a captive, within the limits of the <NORP>Eastern</NORP> empire.
 The prosperity and the health of <PERSON>Roger</PERSON> were already in a declining state: while he listened in his palace of <GPE>Palermo</GPE> to the messengers of victory or defeat, the invincible Manuel, the foremost in every assault, was celebrated by the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> and <NORP>Latins</NORP> as the <PERSON>Alexander</PERSON> or the <PERSON>Hercules</PERSON> of the age.
 He reduces <GPE>Apulia</GPE> and Calabria, A.
D.
 1155.
 A prince of such a temper could not be satisfied with having repelled the insolence of a Barbarian.
 It was the right and duty, it might be the interest and glory, of <PERSON>Manuel</PERSON> to restore the ancient majesty of the empire, to recover the provinces of <GPE>Italy</GPE> and Sicily, and to chastise this pretended king, the grandson of a <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> vassal.
 (112) The natives of <GPE>Calabria</GPE> were still attached to the <NORP>Greek</NORP> language and worship, which had been inexorably proscribed by the <NORP>Latin</NORP> clergy: after the loss of her dukes, <GPE>Apulia</GPE> was chained as a servile appendage to the crown of Sicily; the founder of the monarchy had ruled by the sword; and his death had abated the fear, without healing the discontent, of his subjects: the feudal government was always pregnant with the seeds of rebellion; and a nephew of <PERSON>Roger</PERSON> himself invited the enemies of his family and nation.
 The majesty of the purple, and a series of <NORP>Hungarian</NORP> and <NORP>Turkish</NORP> wars, prevented <PERSON>Manuel</PERSON> from embarking his person in the <NORP>Italian</NORP> expedition.
 To the brave and noble Palaeologus, his lieutenant, the <NORP>Greek</NORP> monarch entrusted a fleet and army: the siege of <PERSON>Bari</PERSON> was his <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> exploit; and, in every operation, gold as well as steel was the instrument of victory.
 Salerno, and some places along the western coast, maintained their fidelity to the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> king; but he lost in <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> campaigns the greater part of his continental possessions; and the modest emperor, disdaining all flattery and falsehood, was content with the reduction of <CARDINAL>three</CARDINAL> hundred cities or villages of <GPE>Apulia</GPE> and Calabria, whose names and titles were inscribed on all the walls of the palace.
 The prejudices of the <NORP>Latins</NORP> were gratified by a genuine or fictitious donation under the seal of the <NORP>German</NORP> Caesars; (113) His design of acquiring <GPE>Italy</GPE> and the <NORP>Western</NORP> empire, A.

 By the artful speeches, liberal gifts, and unbounded promises, of their <NORP>Eastern</NORP> ally, the free cities were encouraged to persevere in their generous struggle against the despotism of <PERSON>Frederic</PERSON> Barbarossa: the walls of <GPE>Milan</GPE> were rebuilt by the contributions of Manuel; and he poured, says the historian, a river of gold into the bosom of Ancona, whose attachment to the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> was fortified by the jealous enmity of the Venetians.
 (114) The situation and trade of <PERSON>Ancona</PERSON> rendered it an important garrison in the heart of Italy: it was twice besieged by the arms of Frederic; the imperial forces were twice repulsed by the spirit of freedom; that spirit was animated by the ambassador of Constantinople; and the most intrepid patriots, the most faithful servants, were rewarded by the wealth and honours of the <NORP>Byzantine</NORP> court.
 (115) The pride of <PERSON>Manuel</PERSON> disdained and rejected a <NORP>Barbarian</NORP> colleague; his ambition was excited by the hope of stripping the purple from the <NORP>German</NORP> usurpers, and of establishing, in the West, as in the East, his lawful title of sole emperor of the Romans.
 With this view, he solicited the alliance of the people and the bishop of Rome.
 Several of the nobles embraced the cause of the <NORP>Greek</NORP> monarch; the splendid nuptials of his niece with Odo Frangipani secured the support of that powerful family, (116) and his royal standard or image was entertained with due reverence in the ancient metropolis.
 (117) During the quarrel between <PERSON>Frederic</PERSON> and <PERSON>Alexander</PERSON> the Third, the pope twice received in the <FAC>Vatican</FAC> the ambassadors of Constantinople.
 They flattered his piety by the long-promised union of the <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> churches, tempted the avarice of his venal court, and exhorted the <NORP>Roman</NORP> pontiff to seize the just provocation, the favourable moment, to humble the savage insolence of the <PERSON>Alemanni</PERSON> and to acknowledge the true representative of <PERSON>Constantine</PERSON> and Augustus.
 (118) Failure of his designs.
 But these <NORP>Italian</NORP> conquests, this universal reign, soon escaped from the hand of the <NORP>Greek</NORP> emperor.
 His <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> demands were eluded by the prudence of <PERSON>Alexander</PERSON> the Third, who paused on this deep and momentous revolution; (119) nor could the pope be seduced by a personal dispute to renounce the perpetual inheritance of the <NORP>Latin</NORP> name.
 After the reunion with Frederic, he spoke a more peremptory language, confirmed the acts of his predecessors, excommunicated the adherents of Manuel, and pronounced the final separation of the churches, or at least the empires, of <GPE>Constantinople</GPE> and Rome.
 (120) The free cities of <GPE>Lombardy</GPE> no longer remembered their foreign benefactor, and without preserving the friendship of Ancona, he soon incurred the enmity of Venice.
 (121) By his own avarice, or the complaints of his subjects, the <NORP>Greek</NORP> emperor was provoked to arrest the persons, and confiscate the effects, of the <NORP>Venetian</NORP> merchants.
 This violation of the public faith exasperated a free and commercial people: <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> hundred galleys were launched and armed in as many days; they swept the coasts of <LOC>Dalmatia</LOC> and Greece: but after some mutual wounds, the war was terminated by an agreement, inglorious to the empire, insufficient for the republic; and a complete vengeance of these and of fresh injuries was reserved for the succeeding generation.
 The lieutenant of <PERSON>Manuel</PERSON> had informed his sovereign that he was strong enough to quell any domestic revolt of <GPE>Apulia</GPE> and Calabria; but that his forces were inadequate to resist the impending attack of the king of Sicily.
 His prophecy was soon verified: the death of <PERSON>Palaeologus</PERSON> devolved the command on several chiefs, alike eminent in rank, alike defective in military talents; the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> were oppressed by land and sea; and a captive remnant that escaped the swords of the <NORP>Normans</NORP> and Saracens, abjured all future hostility against the person or dominions of their conqueror.
 (122) Yet the king of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> esteemed the courage and constancy of Manuel, who had landed a <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> army on the <NORP>Italian</NORP> shore; he respectfully addressed the new Justinian; Peace with the Normans, A.

 (123) The <NORP>Byzantine</NORP> <ORG>Caesars</ORG> acquiesced in this shadow of dominion, without expecting, perhaps without desiring, the service of a <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> army; and the truce of <CARDINAL>thirty</CARDINAL> <DATE>years</DATE> was not disturbed by any hostilities between <GPE>Sicily</GPE> and Constantinople.
 About the end of that period, the throne of <PERSON>Manuel</PERSON> was usurped by an inhuman tyrant, who had deserved the abhorrence of his country and mankind: the sword of <PERSON>William</PERSON> the Second, the grandson of Roger, was drawn by a fugitive of the <NORP>Comnenian</NORP> race; and the subjects of <PERSON>Andronicus</PERSON> might salute the strangers as friends, since they detested their sovereign as the worst of enemies.
 Last war of the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> and Normans, A.
D.
 1185.
 The <NORP>Latin</NORP> historians (124) expatiate on the rapid progress of the <CARDINAL>four</CARDINAL> counts who invaded <GPE>Romania</GPE> with a fleet and army, and reduced many castles and cities to the obedience of the king of Sicily.
 The <NORP>Greeks</NORP> (125) accuse and magnify the wanton and sacrilegious cruelties that were perpetrated in the sack of Thessalonica, the <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> city of the empire.
 The former deplore the fate of those invincible but unsuspecting warriors who were destroyed by the arts of a vanquished foe.
 The latter applaud, in songs of triumph, the repeated victories of their countrymen on the Sea of Marmora or Propontis, on the banks of the Strymon, and under the walls of Durazzo.
 A revolution which punished the crimes of Andronicus, had united against the <PERSON>Franks</PERSON> the zeal and courage of the successful insurgents: <CARDINAL>ten</CARDINAL> thousand were slain in battle, and Isaac Angelus, the new emperor, might indulge his vanity or vengeance in the treatment of <CARDINAL>four</CARDINAL> thousand captives.
 Such was the event of the last contest between the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> and Normans: before the expiration of <CARDINAL>twenty</CARDINAL> years, the rival nations were lost or degraded in foreign servitude; and the successors of <PERSON>Constantine</PERSON> did not long survive to insult the fall of the <NORP>Sicilian</NORP> monarchy.
 <PERSON>William</PERSON> I.
 the Bad king of Sicily, A.
D.
 1154, Feb.
26 -A.
D.
 1166, <DATE>May</DATE> 7.
 The sceptre of <PERSON>Roger</PERSON> successively devolved to his son and grandson: they might be confounded under the name of William: they are strongly discriminated by the epithets of the bad and the good; but these epithets, which appear to describe the perfection of vice and virtue, cannot strictly be applied to either of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> princes.
 When he was roused to arms by danger and shame, the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> <PERSON>William</PERSON> did not degenerate from the valour of his race; but his temper was slothful; his manners were dissolute; his passions headstrong and mischievous; and the monarch is responsible, not only for his personal vices, but for those of Majo, the great admiral, who abused the confidence, and conspired against the life, of his benefactor.
 From the <NORP>Arabian</NORP> conquest, <GPE>Sicily</GPE> had imbibed a deep tincture of <NORP>Oriental</NORP> manners; the despotism, the pomp, and even the harem, of a sultan; and a <NORP>Christian</NORP> people was oppressed and insulted by the ascendant of the eunuchs, who openly professed, or secretly cherished, the religion of Mahomet.
 An eloquent historian of the times (126) has delineated the misfortunes of his country: (127) the ambition and fall of the ungrateful Majo; the revolt and punishment of his assassins; the imprisonment and deliverance of the king himself; the private feuds that arose from the public confusion; and the various forms of calamity and discord which afflicted Palermo, the island, and the continent, during the reign of <PERSON>William</PERSON> the First, and the minority of his son.
 <PERSON>William</PERSON> II.
 the Good, A.
D.
 1166, <DATE>May</DATE> <CARDINAL>7</CARDINAL> -A.
D.
 1189, Nov.

 The youth, innocence, and beauty of <PERSON>William</PERSON> the Second, (128) endeared him to the nation: the factions were reconciled; the laws were revived; and from the manhood to the premature death of that amiable prince, <GPE>Sicily</GPE> enjoyed a short season of peace, justice, and happiness, whose value was enhanced by the remembrance of the past and the dread of futurity.
 The legitimate male posterity of <PERSON>Tancred</PERSON> of <GPE>Hauteville</GPE> was extinct in the person of the <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> William; but his aunt, the daughter of Roger, had married the most powerful prince of the age; and <PERSON>Henry</PERSON> the Sixth, the son of <PERSON>Frederic</PERSON> Barbarossa, descended from the <LOC>Alps</LOC> to claim the <NORP>Imperial</NORP> crown and the inheritance of his wife.
 Against the unanimous wish of a free people, this inheritance could only be acquired by arms; and I am pleased to transcribe the style and sense of the historian Falcandus, who writes at the moment, and on the spot, with the feelings of a patriot, and the prophetic eye of a statesman.
 Lamentation of the historian Falcandus.
 "Constantia, the daughter of Sicily, nursed from her cradle in the pleasures and plenty, and educated in the arts and manners, of this fortunate isle, departed long since to enrich the <NORP>Barbarians</NORP> with our treasures, and now returns, with her savage allies, to contaminate the beauties of her venerable parent.
 Already I behold the swarms of angry Barbarians: our opulent cities, the places flourishing in a long peace, are shaken with fear, desolated by slaughter, consumed by rapine, and polluted by intemperance and lust.
 I see the massacre or captivity of our citizens, the rapes of our virgins and matrons.
 (129) In this extremity (he interrogates a friend) how must the <NORP>Sicilians</NORP> act? By the unanimous election of a king of valour and experience, <GPE>Sicily</GPE> and <GPE>Calabria</GPE> might yet be preserved; (130) for in the levity of the Apulians, ever eager for new revolutions, I can repose neither confidence nor hope.
 (131) Should <GPE>Calabria</GPE> be lost, the lofty towers, the numerous youth, and the naval strength, of Messina, (132) might guard the passage against a foreign invader.
 If the savage <NORP>Germans</NORP> coalesce with the pirates of Messina; if they destroy with fire the fruitful region, so often wasted by the fires of Mount Aetna, (133) what resource will be left for the interior parts of the island, these noble cities which should never be violated by the hostile footsteps of a Barbarian? (134) <PERSON>Catana</PERSON> has again been overwhelmed by an earthquake: the ancient virtue of <GPE>Syracuse</GPE> expires in poverty and solitude; (135) but <GPE>Palermo</GPE> is still crowned with a diadem, and her triple walls enclose the active multitudes of <NORP>Christians</NORP> and Saracens.
 If the <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> nations, under <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> king, can unite for their common safety, they may rush on the <NORP>Barbarians</NORP> with invincible arms.
 But if the Saracens, fatigued by a repetition of injuries, should now retire and rebel; if they should occupy the castles of the mountains and sea-coast, the unfortunate Christians, exposed to a double attack, and placed as it were between the hammer and the anvil, must resign themselves to hopeless and inevitable servitude.
" (136) We must not forget, that a priest here prefers his country to his religion; and that the Moslems, whose alliance he seeks, were still numerous and powerful in the state of Sicily.
 Conquest of the kingdom of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> by the emperor <PERSON>Henry</PERSON> VI.
 A.
D.
 1194.
 The hopes, or at least the wishes, of <PERSON>Falcandus</PERSON> were at <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> gratified by the free and unanimous election of Tancred, the grandson of the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> king, whose birth was illegitimate, but whose civil and military virtues shone without a blemish.
 During <CARDINAL>four</CARDINAL> years, the term of his life and reign, he stood in arms on the farthest verge of the <NORP>Apulian</NORP> frontier, against the powers of Germany; and the restitution of a royal captive, of <PERSON>Constantia</PERSON> herself, without injury or ransom, may appear to surpass the most liberal measure of policy or reason.
 After his decease, the kingdom of his widow and infant son fell without a struggle; and <PERSON>Henry</PERSON> pursued his victorious march from <GPE>Capua</GPE> to Palermo.
 The political balance of <GPE>Italy</GPE> was destroyed by his success; and if the pope and the free cities had consulted their obvious and real interest, they would have combined the powers of earth and heaven to prevent the dangerous union of the <NORP>German</NORP> empire with the kingdom of Sicily.
 But the subtle policy, for which the <FAC>Vatican</FAC> has so often been praised or arraigned, was on this occasion blind and inactive; and if it were true that <PERSON>Celestine</PERSON> the <ORDINAL>Third</ORDINAL> had kicked away the <NORP>Imperial</NORP> crown from the head of the prostrate Henry, (137) such an act of impotent pride could serve only to cancel an obligation and provoke an enemy.
 The Genoese, who enjoyed a beneficial trade and establishment in Sicily, listened to the promise of his boundless gratitude and speedy departure: (138) their fleet commanded the straits of Messina, and opened the harbour of Palermo; and the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> act of his government was to abolish the privileges, and to seize the property, of these imprudent allies.
 The last hope of <PERSON>Falcandus</PERSON> was defeated by the discord of the <NORP>Christians</NORP> and Mahometans: they fought in the capital; several <CARDINAL>thousands</CARDINAL> of the latter were slain; but their surviving brethren fortified the mountains, and disturbed above <CARDINAL>thirty</CARDINAL> <DATE>years</DATE> the peace of the island.
 By the policy of <PERSON>Frederic</PERSON> the Second, sixty thousand <NORP>Saracens</NORP> were transplanted to <GPE>Nocera</GPE> in Apulia.
 In their wars against the <NORP>Roman</NORP> church, the emperor and his son <PERSON>Mainfroy</PERSON> were strengthened and disgraced by the service of the enemies of Christ; and this national colony maintained their religion and manners in the heart of Italy, till they were extirpated, at the end of the thirteenth century, by the zeal and revenge of the house of Anjou.
 (139) All the calamities which the prophetic orator had deplored were surpassed by the cruelty and avarice of the <NORP>German</NORP> conqueror.
 He violated the royal sepulchres and explored the secret treasures of the palace, Palermo, and the whole kingdom: the pearls and jewels, however precious, might be easily removed; but <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> hundred and sixty horses were laden with the gold and silver of Sicily.
 (140) The young king, his mother and sisters, and the nobles of both sexes, were separately confined in the fortresses of the Alps; and, on the slightest rumour of rebellion, the captives were deprived of life, of their eyes, or of the hope of posterity.
 <PERSON>Constantia</PERSON> herself was touched with sympathy for the miseries of her country; and the heiress of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> line might struggle to check her despotic husband, and to save the patrimony of her new-born son, of an emperor so famous in the next age under the name of <PERSON>Frederic</PERSON> the Second.
 Final extinction of the Normans, A.
D.
 1204.
 Ten <DATE>years</DATE> after this revolution, the <NORP>French</NORP> monarchs annexed to their crown the duchy of Normandy: the sceptre of her ancient dukes had been transmitted, by a granddaughter of <PERSON>William</PERSON> the Conqueror, to the house of Plantagenet; and the adventurous Normans, who had raised so many trophies in France, England, and Ireland, in Apulia, Sicily, and the East, were lost, either in victory or servitude, among the vanquished nations.

 At the mouth of the <LOC>Adriatic</LOC> Gulf, the shores of <GPE>Italy</GPE> and <LOC>Epirus</LOC> incline towards each other.
 The space between <PRODUCT>Brundusium</PRODUCT> and Durazzo, the <NORP>Roman</NORP> passage, is no more than <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> hundred miles; (65) at the last station of Otranto, it is contracted to fifty; (66) and this narrow distance had suggested to <PERSON>Pyrrhus</PERSON> and <PERSON>Pompey</PERSON> the sublime or extravagant idea of a bridge.
 Before the general embarkation, the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> duke despatched <PERSON>Bohemond</PERSON> with <CARDINAL>fifteen</CARDINAL> galleys to seize or threaten the Isle of Corfu, to survey the opposite coast, and to secure a harbour in the neighbourhood of <GPE>Vallona</GPE> for the landing of the troops.
 They passed and landed without perceiving an enemy; and this successful experiment displayed the neglect and decay of the naval power of the Greeks.
 The islands of <LOC>Epirus</LOC> and the maritime towns were subdued by the arms or the name of Robert, who led his fleet and army from <PERSON>Corfu</PERSON> (I use the modern appellation) to the siege of Durazzo.
 That city, the western key of the empire, was guarded by ancient renown, and recent fortifications, by <PERSON>George</PERSON> Palaeologus, a patrician, victorious in the <NORP>Oriental</NORP> wars, and a numerous garrison of <NORP>Albanians</NORP> and Macedonians, who, in every age, have maintained the character of soldiers.
 In the prosecution of his enterprise, the courage of <PERSON>Guiscard</PERSON> was assailed by every form of danger and mischance.
 In the most propitious season of the year, as his fleet passed along the coast, a storm of wind and snow unexpectedly arose: the <LOC>Adriatic</LOC> was swelled by the raging blast of the south, and a new shipwreck confirmed the old infamy of the <NORP>Acroceraunian</NORP> rocks.
 (67) The sails, the masts, and the oars, were shattered or torn away; the sea and shore were covered with the fragments of vessels, with arms and dead bodies; and the greatest part of the provisions were either drowned or damaged.
 The ducal galley was laboriously rescued from the waves, and <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> halted <CARDINAL>seven</CARDINAL> days on the adjacent cape, to collect the relics of his loss, and revive the drooping spirits of his soldiers.
 The <NORP>Normans</NORP> were no longer the bold and experienced mariners who had explored the ocean from <LOC>Greenland</LOC> to Mount Atlas, and who smiled at the petty dangers of the Mediterranean.
 They had wept during the tempest; they were alarmed by the hostile approach of the Venetians, who had been solicited by the prayers and promises of the <NORP>Byzantine</NORP> court.
 The <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> day's action was not disadvantageous to Bohemond, a beardless youth, (68) who led the naval powers of his father.
 All night the galleys of the republic lay on their anchors in the form of a crescent; and the victory of the <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> day was decided by the dexterity of their evolutions, the station of their archers, the weight of their javelins, and the borrowed aid of the <NORP>Greek</NORP> fire.
 The <NORP>Apulian</NORP> and <NORP>Ragusian</NORP> vessels fled to the shore, several were cut from their cables, and dragged away by the conqueror; and a sally from the town carried slaughter and dismay to the tents of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> duke.
 A seasonable relief was poured into Durazzo, and as soon as the besiegers had lost the command of the sea, the islands and maritime towns withdrew from the camp the supply of tribute and provision.
 That camp was soon afflicted with a pestilential disease; <CARDINAL>five</CARDINAL> hundred knights perished by an inglorious death; and the list of burials (if all could obtain a decent burial) amounted to <CARDINAL>ten</CARDINAL> thousand persons.
 Under these calamities, the mind of <PERSON>Guiscard</PERSON> alone was firm and invincible; and while he collected new forces from <GPE>Apulia</GPE> and Sicily, he battered, or scaled, or sapped, the walls of Durazzo.
 But his industry and valour were encountered by equal valour and more perfect industry.
 A movable turret, of a size and capacity to contain <CARDINAL>five</CARDINAL> hundred soldiers, had been rolled forwards to the foot of the rampart: but the descent of the door or drawbridge was checked by an enormous beam, and the wooden structure was constantly consumed by artificial flames.
 The army and the march of the emperor Alexius, April-September.
 While the <NORP>Roman</NORP> empire was attacked by the <NORP>Turks</NORP> in the East, east, and the <NORP>Normans</NORP> in the West, the aged successor of <PERSON>Michael</PERSON> surrendered the sceptre to the hands of Alexius, an illustrious captain, and the founder of the <NORP>Comnenian</NORP> dynasty.
 The princess Anne, his daughter and historian, observes, in her affected style, that even <PERSON>Hercules</PERSON> was unequal to a double combat; and, on this principle, she approves a hasty peace with the Turks, which allowed her father to undertake in person the relief of Durazzo.
 On his accession, <PERSON>Alexius</PERSON> found the camp without soldiers, and the treasury without money; yet such were the vigour and activity of his measures, that in <CARDINAL>six</CARDINAL> months he assembled an army of <CARDINAL>seventy</CARDINAL> thousand men, (69) and performed a march of <CARDINAL>five</CARDINAL> hundred miles.
 His troops were levied in <LOC>Europe</LOC> and Asia, from <LOC>Peloponnesus</LOC> to the Black Sea; his majesty was displayed in the silver arms and rich trappings of the companies of Horse-guards; and the emperor was attended by a train of nobles and princes, some of whom, in rapid succession, had been clothed with the purple, and were indulged by the lenity of the times in a life of affluence and dignity.
 Their youthful ardour might animate the multitude; but their love of pleasure and contempt of subordination were pregnant with disorder and mischief; and their importunate clamours for speedy and decisive action disconcerted the prudence of Alexius, who might have surrounded and starved the besieging army.
 The enumeration of provinces recalls a sad comparison of the past and present limits of the <NORP>Roman</NORP> world: the raw levies were drawn together in haste and terror; and the garrisons of Anatolia, or <LOC>Asia</LOC> Minor, had been purchased by the evacuation of the cities which were immediately occupied by the Turks.
 The strength of the <NORP>Greek</NORP> army consisted in the Varangians, the <NORP>Scandinavian</NORP> guards, whose numbers were recently augmented by a colony of exiles and volunteers from the British Island of Thule.
 Under the yoke of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> conqueror, the <NORP>Danes</NORP> and <LANGUAGE>English</LANGUAGE> were oppressed and united; a band of adventurous youths resolved to desert a land of slavery; the sea was open to their escape; and, in their long pilgrimage, they visited every coast that afforded any hope of liberty and revenge.
 They were entertained in the service of the <NORP>Greek</NORP> emperor; and their <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> station was in a new city on the <NORP>Asiatic</NORP> shore: but <PERSON>Alexius</PERSON> soon recalled them to the defence of his person and palace; and bequeathed to his successors the inheritance of their faith and valour.
 (70) The name of a <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> invader revived the memory of their wrongs: they marched with alacrity against the national foe, and panted to regain in <LOC>Epirus</LOC> the glory which they had lost in the battle of Hastings.
 The <NORP>Varangians</NORP> were supported by some companies of <PERSON>Franks</PERSON> or Latins; and the rebels, who had fled to <GPE>Constantinople</GPE> from the tyranny of Guiscard, were eager to signalize their zeal and gratify their revenge.
 In this emergency, the emperor had not disdained the impure aid of the <NORP>Paulicians</NORP> or <NORP>Manichaeans</NORP> of <LOC>Thrace</LOC> and Bulgaria; and these heretics united with the patience of martyrdom the spirit and discipline of active valour.
 (71) The treaty with the sultan had procured a supply of some thousand Turks; and the arrows of the <NORP>Scythian</NORP> horse were opposed to the lances of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> cavalry.
 On the report and distant prospect of these formidable numbers, <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> assembled a council of his principal officers.
 "You behold," said he, "your danger: it is urgent and inevitable.
 The hills are covered with arms and standards; and the emperor of the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> is accustomed to wars and triumphs.
 Obedience and union are our only safety; and I am ready to yield the command to a more worthy leader.
" The vote and acclamation even of his secret enemies, assured him, in that perilous moment, of their esteem and confidence; and the duke thus continued: "Let us trust in the rewards of victory, and deprive cowardice of the means of escape.
 Let us burn our vessels and our baggage, and give battle on this spot, as if it were the place of our nativity and our burial.
" The resolution was unanimously approved; and, without confining himself to his lines, <PERSON>Guiscard</PERSON> awaited in battle-array the nearer approach of the enemy.
 His rear was covered by a small river; his right wing extended to the sea; his left to the hills: nor was he conscious, perhaps, that on the same ground <PERSON>Caesar</PERSON> and <PERSON>Pompey</PERSON> had formerly disputed the empire of the world.
 (72) Battle of Durazzo, A.
D.
 1081, <DATE>October</DATE> 18.
 Against the advice of his wisest captains, <PERSON>Alexius</PERSON> resolved to risk the event of a general action, and exhorted the garrison of <ORG>Durazzo</ORG> to assist their own deliverance by a well-timed sally from the town.
 He marched in <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> columns to surprise the <NORP>Normans</NORP> before daybreak on <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> different sides: his light cavalry was scattered over the plain; the archers formed the <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> line; and the <NORP>Varangians</NORP> claimed the honours of the vanguard.
 In the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> onset, the battle-axes of the strangers made a deep and bloody impression on the army of Guiscard, which was now reduced to <CARDINAL>fifteen</CARDINAL> thousand men.
 The <NORP>Lombards</NORP> and <NORP>Calabrians</NORP> ignominiously turned their backs; they fled towards the river and the sea; but the bridge had been broken down to check the sally of the garrison, and the coast was lined with the <NORP>Venetian</NORP> galleys, who played their engines among the disorderly throng.
 On the verge of ruin, they were saved by the spirit and conduct of their chiefs.
 Gaita, the wife of Robert, is painted by the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> as a warlike Amazon, a <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> Pallas; less skilful in arts, but not less terrible in arms, than the <NORP>Athenian</NORP> goddess: (73) though wounded by an arrow, she stood her ground, and strove, by her exhortation and example, to rally the flying troops.
 (74) Her female voice was seconded by the more powerful voice and arm of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> duke, as calm in action as he was magnanimous in council: "Whither," he cried aloud, "whither do ye fly? Your enemy is implacable; and death is less grievous than servitude.

 (75) <PERSON>Alexius</PERSON> was not deficient in the duties of a soldier or a general; but he no sooner beheld the slaughter of the Varangians, and the flight of the Turks, than he despised his subjects, and despaired of his fortune.
 The princess Anne, who drops a tear on this melancholy event, is reduced to praise the strength and swiftness of her father's horse, and his vigorous struggle when he was almost overthrown by the stroke of a lance, which had shivered the <NORP>Imperial</NORP> helmet.
 His desperate valour broke through a squadron of <PERSON>Franks</PERSON> who opposed his flight; and after wandering <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> days and as many nights in the mountains, he found some repose, of body, though not of mind, in the walls of Lychnidus.
 The victorious <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> reproached the tardy and feeble pursuit which had suffered the escape of so illustrious a prize: but he consoled his disappointment by the trophies and standards of the field, the wealth and luxury of the <NORP>Byzantine</NORP> camp, and the glory of defeating an army <CARDINAL>five</CARDINAL> times more numerous than his own.

 Return of Robert, and the actions of Bohemond.
 Highly presuming that his person was sufficient for the public safety, he repassed the sea in a single brigantine, and left the remains of the army under the command of his son and the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> counts, exhorting <PERSON>Bohemond</PERSON> to respect the freedom of his peers, and the counts to obey the authority of their leader.

 The emperor <PERSON>Henry</PERSON> III invited by the Greeks, A.

 His death, A.
D.
 1085, July 17.

 (93) Without the appearance of an enemy, a victorious army dispersed or retreated in disorder and consternation; and Alexius, who had trembled for his empire, rejoiced in his deliverance.

 His conquests in Africa, A.
D.
 1122-1152.
 As a penance for his impious war against the successor of St.

 The recent injuries of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> might provoke a just retaliation on the heads of the Saracens: the Normans, whose blood had been mingled with so many subject streams, were encouraged to remember and emulate the naval trophies of their fathers, and in the maturity of their strength they contended with the decline of an <NORP>African</NORP> power.

 His invasion of Greece, A.
D.

 Since the decease of <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> Guiscard, the <NORP>Normans</NORP> had relinquished, above sixty years, their hostile designs against the empire of the East.

 In this invasion, of some moment in the annals of commerce, the <NORP>Normans</NORP> spread themselves by sea, and over the provinces of Greece; and the venerable age of Athens, Thebes, and Corinth, was violated by rapine and cruelty.
 Of the wrongs of Athens, no memorial remains.
 The ancient walls, which encompassed, without guarding, the opulence of Thebes, were scaled by the <NORP>Latin</NORP> Christians; but their sole use of the gospel was to sanctify an oath, that the lawful owners had not secreted any relic of their inheritance or industry.

 As soon as the besiegers had surmounted the labor (their sole labor) of climbing the hill, their general, from the commanding eminence, admired his own victory, and testified his gratitude to Heaven, by tearing from the altar the precious image of Theodore, the tutelary saint.
 The silk weavers of both sexes, whom <PERSON>George</PERSON> transported to Sicily, composed the most valuable part of the spoil; and in comparing the skilful industry of the mechanic with the sloth and cowardice of the soldier, he was heard to exclaim that the distaff and loom were the only weapons which the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> were capable of using.

 Last war of the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> and Normans, A.
D.
 1185.
 The <NORP>Latin</NORP> historians (124) expatiate on the rapid progress of the <CARDINAL>four</CARDINAL> counts who invaded <GPE>Romania</GPE> with a fleet and army, and reduced many castles and cities to the obedience of the king of Sicily.
 The <NORP>Greeks</NORP> (125) accuse and magnify the wanton and sacrilegious cruelties that were perpetrated in the sack of Thessalonica, the <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> city of the empire.
 The former deplore the fate of those invincible but unsuspecting warriors who were destroyed by the arts of a vanquished foe.
 The latter applaud, in songs of triumph, the repeated victories of their countrymen on the Sea of Marmora or Propontis, on the banks of the Strymon, and under the walls of Durazzo.
 A revolution which punished the crimes of Andronicus, had united against the <PERSON>Franks</PERSON> the zeal and courage of the successful insurgents: <CARDINAL>ten</CARDINAL> thousand were slain in battle, and Isaac Angelus, the new emperor, might indulge his vanity or vengeance in the treatment of <CARDINAL>four</CARDINAL> thousand captives.
 Such was the event of the last contest between the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> and Normans: before the expiration of <CARDINAL>twenty</CARDINAL> years, the rival nations were lost or degraded in foreign servitude; and the successors of <PERSON>Constantine</PERSON> did not long survive to insult the fall of the <NORP>Sicilian</NORP> monarchy.

 The sceptre of <PERSON>Roger</PERSON> successively devolved to his son and grandson: they might be confounded under the name of William: they are strongly discriminated by the epithets of the bad and the good; but these epithets, which appear to describe the perfection of vice and virtue, cannot strictly be applied to either of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> princes.
 When he was roused to arms by danger and shame, the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> <PERSON>William</PERSON> did not degenerate from the valour of his race; but his temper was slothful; his manners were dissolute; his passions headstrong and mischievous; and the monarch is responsible, not only for his personal vices, but for those of Majo, the great admiral, who abused the confidence, and conspired against the life, of his benefactor.
 From the <NORP>Arabian</NORP> conquest, <GPE>Sicily</GPE> had imbibed a deep tincture of <NORP>Oriental</NORP> manners; the despotism, the pomp, and even the harem, of a sultan; and a <NORP>Christian</NORP> people was oppressed and insulted by the ascendant of the eunuchs, who openly professed, or secretly cherished, the religion of Mahomet.
 An eloquent historian of the times (126) has delineated the misfortunes of his country: (127) the ambition and fall of the ungrateful Majo; the revolt and punishment of his assassins; the imprisonment and deliverance of the king himself; the private feuds that arose from the public confusion; and the various forms of calamity and discord which afflicted Palermo, the island, and the continent, during the reign of <PERSON>William</PERSON> the First, and the minority of his son.

 The youth, innocence, and beauty of <PERSON>William</PERSON> the Second, (128) endeared him to the nation: the factions were reconciled; the laws were revived; and from the manhood to the premature death of that amiable prince, <GPE>Sicily</GPE> enjoyed a short season of peace, justice, and happiness, whose value was enhanced by the remembrance of the past and the dread of futurity.
 The legitimate male posterity of <PERSON>Tancred</PERSON> of <GPE>Hauteville</GPE> was extinct in the person of the <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> William; but his aunt, the daughter of Roger, had married the most powerful prince of the age; and <PERSON>Henry</PERSON> the Sixth, the son of <PERSON>Frederic</PERSON> Barbarossa, descended from the <LOC>Alps</LOC> to claim the <NORP>Imperial</NORP> crown and the inheritance of his wife.
 Against the unanimous wish of a free people, this inheritance could only be acquired by arms; and I am pleased to transcribe the style and sense of the historian Falcandus, who writes at the moment, and on the spot, with the feelings of a patriot, and the prophetic eye of a statesman.
 Lamentation of the historian Falcandus.
 "Constantia, the daughter of Sicily, nursed from her cradle in the pleasures and plenty, and educated in the arts and manners, of this fortunate isle, departed long since to enrich the <NORP>Barbarians</NORP> with our treasures, and now returns, with her savage allies, to contaminate the beauties of her venerable parent.
 Already I behold the swarms of angry Barbarians: our opulent cities, the places flourishing in a long peace, are shaken with fear, desolated by slaughter, consumed by rapine, and polluted by intemperance and lust.
 I see the massacre or captivity of our citizens, the rapes of our virgins and matrons.
 (129) In this extremity (he interrogates a friend) how must the <NORP>Sicilians</NORP> act? By the unanimous election of a king of valour and experience, <GPE>Sicily</GPE> and <GPE>Calabria</GPE> might yet be preserved; (130) for in the levity of the Apulians, ever eager for new revolutions, I can repose neither confidence nor hope.
 (131) Should <GPE>Calabria</GPE> be lost, the lofty towers, the numerous youth, and the naval strength, of Messina, (132) might guard the passage against a foreign invader.
 If the savage <NORP>Germans</NORP> coalesce with the pirates of Messina; if they destroy with fire the fruitful region, so often wasted by the fires of Mount Aetna, (133) what resource will be left for the interior parts of the island, these noble cities which should never be violated by the hostile footsteps of a Barbarian? (134) <PERSON>Catana</PERSON> has again been overwhelmed by an earthquake: the ancient virtue of <GPE>Syracuse</GPE> expires in poverty and solitude; (135) but <GPE>Palermo</GPE> is still crowned with a diadem, and her triple walls enclose the active multitudes of <NORP>Christians</NORP> and Saracens.
 If the <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> nations, under <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> king, can unite for their common safety, they may rush on the <NORP>Barbarians</NORP> with invincible arms.
 But if the Saracens, fatigued by a repetition of injuries, should now retire and rebel; if they should occupy the castles of the mountains and sea-coast, the unfortunate Christians, exposed to a double attack, and placed as it were between the hammer and the anvil, must resign themselves to hopeless and inevitable servitude.
" (136) We must not forget, that a priest here prefers his country to his religion; and that the Moslems, whose alliance he seeks, were still numerous and powerful in the state of Sicily.
 Conquest of the kingdom of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> by the emperor <PERSON>Henry</PERSON> VI.

 The hopes, or at least the wishes, of <PERSON>Falcandus</PERSON> were at <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> gratified by the free and unanimous election of Tancred, the grandson of the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> king, whose birth was illegitimate, but whose civil and military virtues shone without a blemish.

 After his decease, the kingdom of his widow and infant son fell without a struggle; and <PERSON>Henry</PERSON> pursued his victorious march from <GPE>Capua</GPE> to Palermo.
 The political balance of <GPE>Italy</GPE> was destroyed by his success; and if the pope and the free cities had consulted their obvious and real interest, they would have combined the powers of earth and heaven to prevent the dangerous union of the <NORP>German</NORP> empire with the kingdom of Sicily.
 But the subtle policy, for which the <FAC>Vatican</FAC> has so often been praised or arraigned, was on this occasion blind and inactive; and if it were true that <PERSON>Celestine</PERSON> the <ORDINAL>Third</ORDINAL> had kicked away the <NORP>Imperial</NORP> crown from the head of the prostrate Henry, (137) such an act of impotent pride could serve only to cancel an obligation and provoke an enemy.

 By the policy of <PERSON>Frederic</PERSON> the Second, sixty thousand <NORP>Saracens</NORP> were transplanted to <GPE>Nocera</GPE> in Apulia.
 In their wars against the <NORP>Roman</NORP> church, the emperor and his son <PERSON>Mainfroy</PERSON> were strengthened and disgraced by the service of the enemies of Christ; and this national colony maintained their religion and manners in the heart of Italy, till they were extirpated, at the end of the thirteenth century, by the zeal and revenge of the house of Anjou.
 (139) All the calamities which the prophetic orator had deplored were surpassed by the cruelty and avarice of the <NORP>German</NORP> conqueror.
 He violated the royal sepulchres and explored the secret treasures of the palace, Palermo, and the whole kingdom: the pearls and jewels, however precious, might be easily removed; but <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> hundred and sixty horses were laden with the gold and silver of Sicily.
 (140) The young king, his mother and sisters, and the nobles of both sexes, were separately confined in the fortresses of the Alps; and, on the slightest rumour of rebellion, the captives were deprived of life, of their eyes, or of the hope of posterity.
 <PERSON>Constantia</PERSON> herself was touched with sympathy for the miseries of her country; and the heiress of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> line might struggle to check her despotic husband, and to save the patrimony of her new-born son, of an emperor so famous in the next age under the name of <PERSON>Frederic</PERSON> the Second.
 Final extinction of the Normans, A.
D.

 Ten <DATE>years</DATE> after this revolution, the <NORP>French</NORP> monarchs annexed to their crown the duchy of Normandy: the sceptre of her ancient dukes had been transmitted, by a granddaughter of <PERSON>William</PERSON> the Conqueror, to the house of Plantagenet; and the adventurous Normans, who had raised so many trophies in France, England, and Ireland, in Apulia, Sicily, and the East, were lost, either in victory or servitude, among the vanquished nations.

 While the <NORP>Roman</NORP> empire was attacked by the <NORP>Turks</NORP> in the East, east, and the <NORP>Normans</NORP> in the West, the aged successor of <PERSON>Michael</PERSON> surrendered the sceptre to the hands of Alexius, an illustrious captain, and the founder of the <NORP>Comnenian</NORP> dynasty.

 On his accession, <PERSON>Alexius</PERSON> found the camp without soldiers, and the treasury without money; yet such were the vigour and activity of his measures, that in <CARDINAL>six</CARDINAL> months he assembled an army of <CARDINAL>seventy</CARDINAL> thousand men, (69) and performed a march of <CARDINAL>five</CARDINAL> hundred miles.
 His troops were levied in <LOC>Europe</LOC> and Asia, from <LOC>Peloponnesus</LOC> to the Black Sea; his majesty was displayed in the silver arms and rich trappings of the companies of Horse-guards; and the emperor was attended by a train of nobles and princes, some of whom, in rapid succession, had been clothed with the purple, and were indulged by the lenity of the times in a life of affluence and dignity.
 Their youthful ardour might animate the multitude; but their love of pleasure and contempt of subordination were pregnant with disorder and mischief; and their importunate clamours for speedy and decisive action disconcerted the prudence of Alexius, who might have surrounded and starved the besieging army.
 The enumeration of provinces recalls a sad comparison of the past and present limits of the <NORP>Roman</NORP> world: the raw levies were drawn together in haste and terror; and the garrisons of Anatolia, or <LOC>Asia</LOC> Minor, had been purchased by the evacuation of the cities which were immediately occupied by the Turks.

 On the report and distant prospect of these formidable numbers, <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> assembled a council of his principal officers.
 The vote and acclamation even of his secret enemies, assured him, in that perilous moment, of their esteem and confidence; and the duke thus continued: The resolution was unanimously approved; and, without confining himself to his lines, <PERSON>Guiscard</PERSON> awaited in battle-array the nearer approach of the enemy.

 Against the advice of his wisest captains, <PERSON>Alexius</PERSON> resolved to risk the event of a general action, and exhorted the garrison of <ORG>Durazzo</ORG> to assist their own deliverance by a well-timed sally from the town.

 Return of Robert, and the actions of Bohemond.

 His conquests in Africa, A.
D.

 As a penance for his impious war against the successor of St.

D.

 Of the wrongs of Athens, no memorial remains.

 The <NORP>Latin</NORP> historians (124) expatiate on the rapid progress of the <CARDINAL>four</CARDINAL> counts who invaded <GPE>Romania</GPE> with a fleet and army, and reduced many castles and cities to the obedience of the king of Sicily.
 The <NORP>Greeks</NORP> (125) accuse and magnify the wanton and sacrilegious cruelties that were perpetrated in the sack of Thessalonica, the <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> city of the empire.
 The former deplore the fate of those invincible but unsuspecting warriors who were destroyed by the arts of a vanquished foe.
 The latter applaud, in songs of triumph, the repeated victories of their countrymen on the Sea of Marmora or Propontis, on the banks of the Strymon, and under the walls of Durazzo.
 A revolution which punished the crimes of Andronicus, had united against the <PERSON>Franks</PERSON> the zeal and courage of the successful insurgents: <CARDINAL>ten</CARDINAL> thousand were slain in battle, and Isaac Angelus, the new emperor, might indulge his vanity or vengeance in the treatment of <CARDINAL>four</CARDINAL> thousand captives.
 Such was the event of the last contest between the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> and Normans: before the expiration of <CARDINAL>twenty</CARDINAL> years, the rival nations were lost or degraded in foreign servitude; and the successors of <PERSON>Constantine</PERSON> did not long survive to insult the fall of the <NORP>Sicilian</NORP> monarchy.
 <PERSON>William</PERSON> I.
 the Bad king of Sicily, A.

 The sceptre of <PERSON>Roger</PERSON> successively devolved to his son and grandson: they might be confounded under the name of William: they are strongly discriminated by the epithets of the bad and the good; but these epithets, which appear to describe the perfection of vice and virtue, cannot strictly be applied to either of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> princes.
 When he was roused to arms by danger and shame, the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> <PERSON>William</PERSON> did not degenerate from the valour of his race; but his temper was slothful; his manners were dissolute; his passions headstrong and mischievous; and the monarch is responsible, not only for his personal vices, but for those of Majo, the great admiral, who abused the confidence, and conspired against the life, of his benefactor.
 From the <NORP>Arabian</NORP> conquest, <GPE>Sicily</GPE> had imbibed a deep tincture of <NORP>Oriental</NORP> manners; the despotism, the pomp, and even the harem, of a sultan; and a <NORP>Christian</NORP> people was oppressed and insulted by the ascendant of the eunuchs, who openly professed, or secretly cherished, the religion of Mahomet.
 An eloquent historian of the times (126) has delineated the misfortunes of his country: (127) the ambition and fall of the ungrateful Majo; the revolt and punishment of his assassins; the imprisonment and deliverance of the king himself; the private feuds that arose from the public confusion; and the various forms of calamity and discord which afflicted Palermo, the island, and the continent, during the reign of <PERSON>William</PERSON> the First, and the minority of his son.
 <PERSON>William</PERSON> II.

 The youth, innocence, and beauty of <PERSON>William</PERSON> the Second, (128) endeared him to the nation: the factions were reconciled; the laws were revived; and from the manhood to the premature death of that amiable prince, <GPE>Sicily</GPE> enjoyed a short season of peace, justice, and happiness, whose value was enhanced by the remembrance of the past and the dread of futurity.
 The legitimate male posterity of <PERSON>Tancred</PERSON> of <GPE>Hauteville</GPE> was extinct in the person of the <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> William; but his aunt, the daughter of Roger, had married the most powerful prince of the age; and <PERSON>Henry</PERSON> the Sixth, the son of <PERSON>Frederic</PERSON> Barbarossa, descended from the <LOC>Alps</LOC> to claim the <NORP>Imperial</NORP> crown and the inheritance of his wife.
 Against the unanimous wish of a free people, this inheritance could only be acquired by arms; and I am pleased to transcribe the style and sense of the historian Falcandus, who writes at the moment, and on the spot, with the feelings of a patriot, and the prophetic eye of a statesman.
 Lamentation of the historian Falcandus.
 "Constantia, the daughter of Sicily, nursed from her cradle in the pleasures and plenty, and educated in the arts and manners, of this fortunate isle, departed long since to enrich the <NORP>Barbarians</NORP> with our treasures, and now returns, with her savage allies, to contaminate the beauties of her venerable parent.
 Already I behold the swarms of angry Barbarians: our opulent cities, the places flourishing in a long peace, are shaken with fear, desolated by slaughter, consumed by rapine, and polluted by intemperance and lust.
 I see the massacre or captivity of our citizens, the rapes of our virgins and matrons.
 (129) In this extremity (he interrogates a friend) how must the <NORP>Sicilians</NORP> act? By the unanimous election of a king of valour and experience, <GPE>Sicily</GPE> and <GPE>Calabria</GPE> might yet be preserved; (130) for in the levity of the Apulians, ever eager for new revolutions, I can repose neither confidence nor hope.
 (131) Should <GPE>Calabria</GPE> be lost, the lofty towers, the numerous youth, and the naval strength, of Messina, (132) might guard the passage against a foreign invader.
 If the savage <NORP>Germans</NORP> coalesce with the pirates of Messina; if they destroy with fire the fruitful region, so often wasted by the fires of Mount Aetna, (133) what resource will be left for the interior parts of the island, these noble cities which should never be violated by the hostile footsteps of a Barbarian? (134) <PERSON>Catana</PERSON> has again been overwhelmed by an earthquake: the ancient virtue of <GPE>Syracuse</GPE> expires in poverty and solitude; (135) but <GPE>Palermo</GPE> is still crowned with a diadem, and her triple walls enclose the active multitudes of <NORP>Christians</NORP> and Saracens.
 If the <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> nations, under <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> king, can unite for their common safety, they may rush on the <NORP>Barbarians</NORP> with invincible arms.
 But if the Saracens, fatigued by a repetition of injuries, should now retire and rebel; if they should occupy the castles of the mountains and sea-coast, the unfortunate Christians, exposed to a double attack, and placed as it were between the hammer and the anvil, must resign themselves to hopeless and inevitable servitude.
" (136) We must not forget, that a priest here prefers his country to his religion; and that the Moslems, whose alliance he seeks, were still numerous and powerful in the state of Sicily.
 Conquest of the kingdom of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> by the emperor <PERSON>Henry</PERSON> VI.

 The hopes, or at least the wishes, of <PERSON>Falcandus</PERSON> were at <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> gratified by the free and unanimous election of Tancred, the grandson of the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> king, whose birth was illegitimate, but whose civil and military virtues shone without a blemish.

 The political balance of <GPE>Italy</GPE> was destroyed by his success; and if the pope and the free cities had consulted their obvious and real interest, they would have combined the powers of earth and heaven to prevent the dangerous union of the <NORP>German</NORP> empire with the kingdom of Sicily.
 But the subtle policy, for which the <FAC>Vatican</FAC> has so often been praised or arraigned, was on this occasion blind and inactive; and if it were true that <PERSON>Celestine</PERSON> the <ORDINAL>Third</ORDINAL> had kicked away the <NORP>Imperial</NORP> crown from the head of the prostrate Henry, (137) such an act of impotent pride could serve only to cancel an obligation and provoke an enemy.
 The Genoese, who enjoyed a beneficial trade and establishment in Sicily, listened to the promise of his boundless gratitude and speedy departure: (138) their fleet commanded the straits of Messina, and opened the harbour of Palermo; and the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> act of his government was to abolish the privileges, and to seize the property, of these imprudent allies.
 The last hope of <PERSON>Falcandus</PERSON> was defeated by the discord of the <NORP>Christians</NORP> and Mahometans: they fought in the capital; several <CARDINAL>thousands</CARDINAL> of the latter were slain; but their surviving brethren fortified the mountains, and disturbed above <CARDINAL>thirty</CARDINAL> <DATE>years</DATE> the peace of the island.
 By the policy of <PERSON>Frederic</PERSON> the Second, sixty thousand <NORP>Saracens</NORP> were transplanted to <GPE>Nocera</GPE> in Apulia.
 In their wars against the <NORP>Roman</NORP> church, the emperor and his son <PERSON>Mainfroy</PERSON> were strengthened and disgraced by the service of the enemies of Christ; and this national colony maintained their religion and manners in the heart of Italy, till they were extirpated, at the end of the thirteenth century, by the zeal and revenge of the house of Anjou.
 (139) All the calamities which the prophetic orator had deplored were surpassed by the cruelty and avarice of the <NORP>German</NORP> conqueror.
 He violated the royal sepulchres and explored the secret treasures of the palace, Palermo, and the whole kingdom: the pearls and jewels, however precious, might be easily removed; but <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> hundred and sixty horses were laden with the gold and silver of Sicily.
 (140) The young king, his mother and sisters, and the nobles of both sexes, were separately confined in the fortresses of the Alps; and, on the slightest rumour of rebellion, the captives were deprived of life, of their eyes, or of the hope of posterity.
 <PERSON>Constantia</PERSON> herself was touched with sympathy for the miseries of her country; and the heiress of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> line might struggle to check her despotic husband, and to save the patrimony of her new-born son, of an emperor so famous in the next age under the name of <PERSON>Frederic</PERSON> the Second.
 Final extinction of the Normans, A.
D.
 1204.
 Ten <DATE>years</DATE> after this revolution, the <NORP>French</NORP> monarchs annexed to their crown the duchy of Normandy: the sceptre of her ancient dukes had been transmitted, by a granddaughter of <PERSON>William</PERSON> the Conqueror, to the house of Plantagenet; and the adventurous Normans, who had raised so many trophies in France, England, and Ireland, in Apulia, Sicily, and the East, were lost, either in victory or servitude, among the vanquished nations.

 Against the advice of his wisest captains, <PERSON>Alexius</PERSON> resolved to risk the event of a general action, and exhorted the garrison of <ORG>Durazzo</ORG> to assist their own deliverance by a well-timed sally from the town.

 On the verge of ruin, they were saved by the spirit and conduct of their chiefs.

 (74) Her female voice was seconded by the more powerful voice and arm of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> duke, as calm in action as he was magnanimous in council: The moment was decisive: as the <NORP>Varangians</NORP> advanced before the line, they discovered the nakedness of their flanks: the main battle of the duke, of eight hundred knights, stood firm and entire; they couched their lances, and the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> deplore the furious and irresistible shock of the <NORP>French</NORP> cavalry.
 (75) <PERSON>Alexius</PERSON> was not deficient in the duties of a soldier or a general; but he no sooner beheld the slaughter of the Varangians, and the flight of the Turks, than he despised his subjects, and despaired of his fortune.

 The victorious <PERSON>Robert</PERSON> reproached the tardy and feeble pursuit which had suffered the escape of so illustrious a prize: but he consoled his disappointment by the trophies and standards of the field, the wealth and luxury of the <NORP>Byzantine</NORP> camp, and the glory of defeating an army <CARDINAL>five</CARDINAL> times more numerous than his own.

 <ORG>Durazzo</ORG> taken, A.
D.

 It is more than probable that <PERSON>Guiscard</PERSON> was not afflicted by the loss of a costly pageant, which had merited only the contempt and derision of the Greeks.

 Return of Robert, and the actions of Bohemond.
 Highly presuming that his person was sufficient for the public safety, he repassed the sea in a single brigantine, and left the remains of the army under the command of his son and the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> counts, exhorting <PERSON>Bohemond</PERSON> to respect the freedom of his peers, and the counts to obey the authority of their leader.

 Yet a just praise must not be refused to the fortitude and prudence of Alexius, who bravely struggled with the calamities of the times.

 In the neighbourhood of <GPE>Larissa</GPE> the events of war were protracted and balanced.

 The want of experience had been supplied by the genius of Guiscard; and each evening, when he had sounded a retreat, he calmly explored the causes of his repulse, and invented new methods how to remedy his own defects, and to baffle the advantages of the enemy.

 (93) Without the appearance of an enemy, a victorious army dispersed or retreated in disorder and consternation; and Alexius, who had trembled for his empire, rejoiced in his deliverance.

 His conquests in Africa, A.
D.

 As a penance for his impious war against the successor of St.

 Last war of the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> and Normans, A.

 <PERSON>William</PERSON> I.

 The sceptre of <PERSON>Roger</PERSON> successively devolved to his son and grandson: they might be confounded under the name of William: they are strongly discriminated by the epithets of the bad and the good; but these epithets, which appear to describe the perfection of vice and virtue, cannot strictly be applied to either of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> princes.

 From the <NORP>Arabian</NORP> conquest, <GPE>Sicily</GPE> had imbibed a deep tincture of <NORP>Oriental</NORP> manners; the despotism, the pomp, and even the harem, of a sultan; and a <NORP>Christian</NORP> people was oppressed and insulted by the ascendant of the eunuchs, who openly professed, or secretly cherished, the religion of Mahomet.
 An eloquent historian of the times (126) has delineated the misfortunes of his country: (127) the ambition and fall of the ungrateful Majo; the revolt and punishment of his assassins; the imprisonment and deliverance of the king himself; the private feuds that arose from the public confusion; and the various forms of calamity and discord which afflicted Palermo, the island, and the continent, during the reign of <PERSON>William</PERSON> the First, and the minority of his son.

 The youth, innocence, and beauty of <PERSON>William</PERSON> the Second, (128) endeared him to the nation: the factions were reconciled; the laws were revived; and from the manhood to the premature death of that amiable prince, <GPE>Sicily</GPE> enjoyed a short season of peace, justice, and happiness, whose value was enhanced by the remembrance of the past and the dread of futurity.
 The legitimate male posterity of <PERSON>Tancred</PERSON> of <GPE>Hauteville</GPE> was extinct in the person of the <ORDINAL>second</ORDINAL> William; but his aunt, the daughter of Roger, had married the most powerful prince of the age; and <PERSON>Henry</PERSON> the Sixth, the son of <PERSON>Frederic</PERSON> Barbarossa, descended from the <LOC>Alps</LOC> to claim the <NORP>Imperial</NORP> crown and the inheritance of his wife.
 Against the unanimous wish of a free people, this inheritance could only be acquired by arms; and I am pleased to transcribe the style and sense of the historian Falcandus, who writes at the moment, and on the spot, with the feelings of a patriot, and the prophetic eye of a statesman.
 Lamentation of the historian Falcandus.
 "Constantia, the daughter of Sicily, nursed from her cradle in the pleasures and plenty, and educated in the arts and manners, of this fortunate isle, departed long since to enrich the <NORP>Barbarians</NORP> with our treasures, and now returns, with her savage allies, to contaminate the beauties of her venerable parent.
 Already I behold the swarms of angry Barbarians: our opulent cities, the places flourishing in a long peace, are shaken with fear, desolated by slaughter, consumed by rapine, and polluted by intemperance and lust.
 I see the massacre or captivity of our citizens, the rapes of our virgins and matrons.
 (129) In this extremity (he interrogates a friend) how must the <NORP>Sicilians</NORP> act? By the unanimous election of a king of valour and experience, <GPE>Sicily</GPE> and <GPE>Calabria</GPE> might yet be preserved; (130) for in the levity of the Apulians, ever eager for new revolutions, I can repose neither confidence nor hope.
 (131) Should <GPE>Calabria</GPE> be lost, the lofty towers, the numerous youth, and the naval strength, of Messina, (132) might guard the passage against a foreign invader.
 If the savage <NORP>Germans</NORP> coalesce with the pirates of Messina; if they destroy with fire the fruitful region, so often wasted by the fires of Mount Aetna, (133) what resource will be left for the interior parts of the island, these noble cities which should never be violated by the hostile footsteps of a Barbarian? (134) <PERSON>Catana</PERSON> has again been overwhelmed by an earthquake: the ancient virtue of <GPE>Syracuse</GPE> expires in poverty and solitude; (135) but <GPE>Palermo</GPE> is still crowned with a diadem, and her triple walls enclose the active multitudes of <NORP>Christians</NORP> and Saracens.
 If the <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> nations, under <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> king, can unite for their common safety, they may rush on the <NORP>Barbarians</NORP> with invincible arms.
 But if the Saracens, fatigued by a repetition of injuries, should now retire and rebel; if they should occupy the castles of the mountains and sea-coast, the unfortunate Christians, exposed to a double attack, and placed as it were between the hammer and the anvil, must resign themselves to hopeless and inevitable servitude.
" (136) We must not forget, that a priest here prefers his country to his religion; and that the Moslems, whose alliance he seeks, were still numerous and powerful in the state of Sicily.
 Conquest of the kingdom of <GPE>Sicily</GPE> by the emperor <PERSON>Henry</PERSON> VI.
 A.
D.
 1194.
 The hopes, or at least the wishes, of <PERSON>Falcandus</PERSON> were at <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> gratified by the free and unanimous election of Tancred, the grandson of the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> king, whose birth was illegitimate, but whose civil and military virtues shone without a blemish.
 During <CARDINAL>four</CARDINAL> years, the term of his life and reign, he stood in arms on the farthest verge of the <NORP>Apulian</NORP> frontier, against the powers of Germany; and the restitution of a royal captive, of <PERSON>Constantia</PERSON> herself, without injury or ransom, may appear to surpass the most liberal measure of policy or reason.
 After his decease, the kingdom of his widow and infant son fell without a struggle; and <PERSON>Henry</PERSON> pursued his victorious march from <GPE>Capua</GPE> to Palermo.
 The political balance of <GPE>Italy</GPE> was destroyed by his success; and if the pope and the free cities had consulted their obvious and real interest, they would have combined the powers of earth and heaven to prevent the dangerous union of the <NORP>German</NORP> empire with the kingdom of Sicily.
 But the subtle policy, for which the <FAC>Vatican</FAC> has so often been praised or arraigned, was on this occasion blind and inactive; and if it were true that <PERSON>Celestine</PERSON> the <ORDINAL>Third</ORDINAL> had kicked away the <NORP>Imperial</NORP> crown from the head of the prostrate Henry, (137) such an act of impotent pride could serve only to cancel an obligation and provoke an enemy.
 The Genoese, who enjoyed a beneficial trade and establishment in Sicily, listened to the promise of his boundless gratitude and speedy departure: (138) their fleet commanded the straits of Messina, and opened the harbour of Palermo; and the <ORDINAL>first</ORDINAL> act of his government was to abolish the privileges, and to seize the property, of these imprudent allies.
 The last hope of <PERSON>Falcandus</PERSON> was defeated by the discord of the <NORP>Christians</NORP> and Mahometans: they fought in the capital; several <CARDINAL>thousands</CARDINAL> of the latter were slain; but their surviving brethren fortified the mountains, and disturbed above <CARDINAL>thirty</CARDINAL> <DATE>years</DATE> the peace of the island.
 By the policy of <PERSON>Frederic</PERSON> the Second, sixty thousand <NORP>Saracens</NORP> were transplanted to <GPE>Nocera</GPE> in Apulia.
 In their wars against the <NORP>Roman</NORP> church, the emperor and his son <PERSON>Mainfroy</PERSON> were strengthened and disgraced by the service of the enemies of Christ; and this national colony maintained their religion and manners in the heart of Italy, till they were extirpated, at the end of the thirteenth century, by the zeal and revenge of the house of Anjou.
 (139) All the calamities which the prophetic orator had deplored were surpassed by the cruelty and avarice of the <NORP>German</NORP> conqueror.
 He violated the royal sepulchres and explored the secret treasures of the palace, Palermo, and the whole kingdom: the pearls and jewels, however precious, might be easily removed; but <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> hundred and sixty horses were laden with the gold and silver of Sicily.
 (140) The young king, his mother and sisters, and the nobles of both sexes, were separately confined in the fortresses of the Alps; and, on the slightest rumour of rebellion, the captives were deprived of life, of their eyes, or of the hope of posterity.
 <PERSON>Constantia</PERSON> herself was touched with sympathy for the miseries of her country; and the heiress of the <PERSON>Norman</PERSON> line might struggle to check her despotic husband, and to save the patrimony of her new-born son, of an emperor so famous in the next age under the name of <PERSON>Frederic</PERSON> the Second.
 Final extinction of the Normans, A.
D.
 1204.
 Ten <DATE>years</DATE> after this revolution, the <NORP>French</NORP> monarchs annexed to their crown the duchy of Normandy: the sceptre of her ancient dukes had been transmitted, by a granddaughter of <PERSON>William</PERSON> the Conqueror, to the house of Plantagenet; and the adventurous Normans, who had raised so many trophies in France, England, and Ireland, in Apulia, Sicily, and the East, were lost, either in victory or servitude, among the vanquished nations.
